caption.title: The dynamics of the ‘dual reporters’ X and Y are not necessarily symmetric despite the fact that X and Y have the same production rate.
caption.p: (A) Feedback in gene regulation can suppress or amplify fluctuations in the abundances of molecular species. Here we show an example system of the class of Equation 1, where X affects the shared transcription rate of X and,Y but does not affect the shared upstream variable Z. In this example, the intrinsic fluctuations of X are suppressed through negative feedback, whereas those from Y are not. This leads to unequal dynamics and cell-to-cell variability in X and Y levels. See Section 10 for details of the simulated example system. (B) The invariant Equation 2 does not hold in terms of Pearson correlation coefficients, i.e., ρxz≠ρyz\begin{document}$ \rho_{xz}\neq\rho_{yz}$\end{document} even when X does not affect Z. In this example system, the divergence between ρxz\begin{document}$ \rho_{xz}$\end{document} and ρyz\begin{document}$ \rho_{yz}$\end{document} increases as the feedback strength increases (see Section 10). In contrast, Equation 2 constrains all systems in which X does not affect Z, even when the X and Y levels have vastly different dynamics and cell-to-cell variability. Note, the covariances and correlations can be determined from the static snapshots of cell-to-cell variability indicated in panel A. The time-trace to indicate the dynamics of the reporters is for illustration purposes only.

caption.title: Using the null hypothesis test on the measured covariability ratios.
caption.p: Using the null hypothesis test on the measured covariability ratios. (A) Plotted are the measured covariability ratios ηxz/ηyz\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}$\end{document} for synthetic circuits shown in Figure 3D and Appendix 1—figure 17 in which X affects Z. Error bars correspond to estimated 95% confidence intervals, which were determined with error propagation (using the uncertainties python package) using the 95% confidence intervals for ηxz\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}$\end{document} and ηyz\begin{document}$ \eta_{yz}$\end{document} that were estimated as detailed in Section 17 and the Materials and methods of the main text. Under the null hypothesis that there is no causal interaction from X to Z, the expected value of ηxz/ηyz=1\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}=1$\end{document}. If the measured covariability ratio is above (below) the expected value of 1, then there is a 2.5% probability that the expected value of 1 falls below (above) the lower (upper) error bar. As a result, under a significance level of 2.5%, we say there is a causal interaction from X to Z if the value of ηxz/ηyz=1\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}=1$\end{document} does not fall within the measured 95% confidence intervals. Using this rule, our method detected two causal interactions (synthetic circuits #1 and #2) out of four. (B) Under the rule for detecting causality outlined in A, we detect a causal interaction in synthetic circuit #12 when we set the RFP concentration as the Z component of interest. Plotted are the measured covariability ratios ηxz/ηyz\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}$\end{document} for the synthetic circuits shown in Figure 3E and Appendix 1—figures 18 and 19. (C) Similarly to B, we detect a causal interaction in synthetic circuit # 12 when we set the growth rate as the Z component of interest. All other negative control circuits satisfy the null hypothesis test.

caption.title: Percentage uncertainty distributions for individual simulated processes — part 1.
caption.p: Plotted are the computed normalized covariances from the simulated concentrations of growing and dividing cells in processes 1–5 (as listed in Appendix 1—table 1). Each number in the top left corners corresponds to the process index listed in Appendix 1—table 1. For each process, a number of random parameters were chosen and simulated as described in the Materials and methods section of the main text. On the left of each subplot are the normalized covariances for each of the parameter sets simulated in the respective process. Error bars are present but are almost always too small to be visible. On the right of each subplot is the distribution of percentage uncertainty, defined as σxz/|ηxz|×100%\begin{document}$ \sigma_{xz}/|\eta_{xz}|\times 100\%$\end{document} and σyz/|ηyz|×100%\begin{document}$ \sigma_{yz}/|\eta_{yz}|\times 100\%$\end{document}, where σxz\begin{document}$ \sigma_{xz}$\end{document} is the estimated 95% confidence interval for ηxz\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}$\end{document}. Most of the percentage errors fall below 5%. However, occasionally a parameter set is chosen that leads to either rare birth and death events in the stochastic process, which leads to low sampling, or the particular parameters lead to near zero normalized covariances, which can lead to large percentage errors. Colors of dots and error bars in the left plots correspond to the same colors plotted in the combined figure of Figure 2.

caption.title: Percentage uncertainty distributions for individual simulated processes — part 2.
caption.p: Same as Appendix 1—figure 3 but for processes 6 to 10 (as listed in Appendix 1—table 1).

caption.title: Percentage of simulations that deviate from the invariant of Equation 2.
caption.p: (A) Plotted is the percentage of simulated parameter sets for each simulated process (as listed in Appendix 1—table 1) that did not produce normalized covariances that satisfied Equation 2. Specifically, the 95% confidence interval for the ratio ηxz/ηyz\begin{document}$\eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}$\end{document} in these ‘outlier’ simulations did not capture the predicted value of 1. It is expected that not all simulations will agree with Equation 2 due to sampling errors. The largest outlier percentage is for process 5, which has 5.01% of simulations that did not satisfy Equation 2. As described in the Materials and Methods section of the main text, all outlier systems were simulated again with additional sampling which resulted in agreement with Equation 2. (B) Plotted is the number of parameter sets simulated for each process. Some processes took less time to simulate and, as a result, resulted in a larger number of parameter sets. All processes were simulated for at least 100 parameter sets.

caption.title: Estimating uncertainty with a second method does not change the results of Figure 3D,E.
caption.p: Shown are the measured normalized covariances for the synthetic positive control circuits (left) and negative control circuits (right), where error bars are computed by splitting the ensemble of single-cell traces into 7-10 disjoint sets. Final normalized covariances are taken as the averages of the sets, with 95% confidence intervals given by two times the standard error of the mean (plotted error bars). Data corrections such as non-even illumination correction and autofluorescence removal were done separately on each set in order to estimate the error of these corrections. Autofluorescence and imaging media fluorescence were corrected by analyzing cells that lost the synthetic plasmid due to random partitioning at cell division, as described in Materials and methods. If 10 or more cells from an experiment lost the plasmid, then the single-cell traces were randomly split into 10 disjoint sets, both with and without the plasmid. Otherwise, the number of disjoint sets was set as the number of cells that lost the plasmid (a minimum of 7), so that each set would contain at least one cell that lost the plasmid to estimate the autofluorescence. This is described in the Materials and methods section of the main text, as well as in Appendix 1—figure 16 and Section 17.

caption.title: The outlier circuit does not satisfy Equation 2 after switching the fluorescent proteins.
caption.p: (A) To rule out the possibility that the outlier in Figure 3E was caused by a systematic error from an asymmetry between measurements of the CFP and YFP fluorescence signals, we rebuilt the outlier circuit, but with cfp fused to tetR and yfp set as the transcriptional passive reporter. If the outlier was caused by such a systematic error, then the normalized covariance measurements would switch to the other side of the dashed line. (B) The normalized covariances still do not satisfy Equation 2, and they do not switch to the other side of the dashed line. Two repeats of the experiment are shown. Note that the numerical values for the normalized covariances are different than the outlier circuit in Figure 3E. This could be indicative that the CFP protein used changes the TetR function when used as a fusion.

caption.title: Using a different cell segmentation pipeline does not alter the main result of Figure 3E .
caption.p: For the results shown in Figure 3 we used the deep-learning cell segmentation pipeline DeLTA (O’Connor et al., 2022), see Materials and Methods. We used the DeLTA pipeline to segment cells with the bright field channel because the three fluorescence channels (CFP, YFP, and RFP) were not always bright enough in the positive control strains to use as a segmentation marker. However, in all the negative control strains, RFP is under the control of the strong pRNA1 promoter which has been used as a segmentation marker previously (Potvin-Trottier et al., 2016; Lord et al., 2019). We thus applied the same segmentation pipeline used in Potvin-Trottier et al., 2016; Lord et al., 2019 on the RFP channel of the negative control strains. The numerical values of the normalized covariances change slightly, but their relation to Equation 2 remains intact. This second segmentation pipeline determines the edges of the cells using a thresholding algorithm, and it estimates background fluorescence by taking the median of the median of each image; see Lord et al., 2019 for details. The autofluorescence of strains 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10 was not removed because these strains express RFP from the plasmid, so cells that lost the plasmid (which we use to estimate autofluorescence, see Materials and Methods) cannot be tracked with this pipeline.

caption.title: In the outlier circuit, large RFP fluctuations are often negatively correlated with growth rate fluctuations.
caption.p: We observed many instances in which RFP concentration was negatively correlated with fluctuations in the cellular growth rate. Shown are three sample single-cell traces. The top two are from the outlier circuit, whereas the bottom trace is from the outlier circuit with swapped fluorescent proteins (see Appendix 1—figure 7A). Dots correspond to times at which a cell division has been detected. (B) To quantify this trend over all lineages, we used the cross-correlation function Crfp,g(τ)\begin{document}$C_{\text{rfp}, \text{g}}(\tau)$\end{document} between the RFP concentration and growth rate (g) in the outlier circuit. We observe a negative correlation time shifted by approximately 1 hr. Crfp,g(τ)\begin{document}$C_{\text{rfp}, \text{g}}(\tau)$\end{document} quantifies how the RFP concentration is correlated with growth rate when the growth rate signal is shifted by time τ relative to the RFP signal. Crfp,g(τ)\begin{document}$C_{\text{rfp}, \text{g}}(\tau)$\end{document} was computed using the python scipy function correlate on each single-cell trajectories while normalizing by Crfp,rfp(0)Cg,g(0)\begin{document}$\sqrt{C_{\text{rfp}, \text{rfp}}(0) C_{\text{g}, \text{g}}(0)}$\end{document}. The dark line corresponds to the average at time τ over all trajectories, with the width of the shaded region given by the standard deviation about the mean.

caption.title: The outlier circuit shows more variability in RFP concentrations and growth rate measurements as compared to other strains that express RFP from the chromosome with the pRNA1 promoter.
caption.p: (A) The ‘regular’ repressilator circuit without endogenous LacI also exhibits negative correlation between RFP and growth rate, albeit with smaller magnitude. Shown are the cross correlations (defined in Appendix 1—figure 9B) for the outlier circuit (left), the strain with the regular repressilator (outlier circuit with lacI deletion, middle), and the background strain without a plasmid but with RFP still expressed (right). In all cases, RFP is expressed from the chromosome under the control of the same pRNA1 promoter. The outlier circuit exhibits slightly more negative correlation. Below each cross-correlation plot is a sample time-trace for a cell with the respective circuit. Dots correspond to times at which a cell division has been detected. (B) The ‘regular’ repressilator circuit without endogenous LacI does not exhibit the same degree of growth rate fluctuations and does not exhibit as pronounced RFP pulses. The size of the fluctuations of the growth rate and RFP concentration was measured as the coefficient of variability (CV), defined as CVz=Var(z)/⟨z⟩\begin{document}$\text{CV}_{z} = \sqrt{Var(z)}/\langle z \rangle$\end{document}. The CVs were measured for the outlier circuit, the strain with the regular repressilator (outlier circuit with lacI deletion), and the background strain without a plasmid but with RFP still expressed. The outlier circuit exhibits a larger CV in both cases, suggesting that the outlier circuit causes the increased growth rate fluctuations. Orange error bars correspond to 95% confidence intervals estimated using the same bootstrapping approach used for the normalized covariances described in the Materials and Methods of the main text.

caption.title: RpoS activity often displayed pulses that are negatively correlated with growth rate.
caption.p: We observed many instances in which RpoS activity, quantified by a transcriptional GFP reporter under the control of the gadX promoter, was negatively correlated with fluctuations in the cellular growth rate. Shown are three sample single-cell traces. (B) To quantify this trend over all lineages, we used the cross-correlation function Cgfp,g(τ)\begin{document}$ C_{\text{gfp},\text{g}}(\tau)$\end{document} between the GFP concentration and growth rate (g). We observe a negative correlation time shifted by approximately 1 hr. Cgfp,g(τ)\begin{document}$ C_{\text{gfp},\text{g}}(\tau)$\end{document} quantifies how the GFP concentration is correlated with growth rate when the growth rate signal is shifted by time τ\begin{document}$ \tau$\end{document} relative to the GFP signal. It was computed as described in the Appendix 1—figure 9 caption.

caption.title: Removing the pRNA1 controlled rfp gene changes the TetR dynamics of the outlier circuit and increases the growth rate.
caption.p: One of the positive control circuits (4) contains the same synthetic circuit as the outlier circuit, but without the pRNA1 controlled rfp on the chromosome, and instead a pLtetO1 controlled rfp gene on the plasmid. We observed that the TetR dynamics, quantified by YFP, were different than in the outlier circuit as they displayed random large pulses. The RFP levels, in turn, also displayed random large pulses when the TetR levels were reduced. To quantify these observations over all lineages, we computed the CV for the TetR levels for both strains (top right). The strain 4 CV is larger. We also computed the average growth rate for both strains and found that the strain 4 growth rate is approximately 9% larger. These results suggest that the pRNA1-controlled rfp gene affected the rest of the circuit elements, along with the cellular growth rate, which we hypothesize is from burden caused by resource competition. Error bars correspond to 95% confidence intervals using the bootstrapping approach used for the normalized covariances as discussed in the Materials and methods section.

caption.title: Correcting for temporal drift of the focal points.
caption.p: (A) Individual average fluorescence measurements (taken over cell area) are binned according to their timeframe. The average of the measurements at each timeframe is plotted. A second-degree polynomial is fitted to the resulting time-traces using a least squares fit. Shown is data from the strain 6 in Appendix 1—figure 18. The YFP and CFP time-traces fluctuate more than the RFP time-trace due to the large pulses that they display from the Repressilator. (B) Temporal drift is corrected by multiplying all of the individual average fluorescence measurements with the reciprocal of the fits. Plotted is the average time-traces taken from the corrected data, along with new fits that display constant trends.

caption.title: Estimating autofluorescence and media fluorescence with cells that lost plasmid.
caption.p: (A) A single-cell time trace from a mother machine experiment in which the plasmid is kept for the entire duration of the experiment. On the top is the cell area over time displaying cellular growth and division, and on the bottom are the average YFP and CFP signals taken over the cell area. Note that autofluorescence and media fluorescence have not been corrected for here. (B) A single-cell time trace in which the plasmid containing the synthetic circuit is lost. The signals decay to constant values just above zero. The cell area continues to grow and divide, indicating that the decay is not the result of segmentation error or loss of cell.

caption.title: Correcting for background and uneven illumination.
caption.p: (A) Plotted is the fluorescence intensity profile across the dashed orange line shown in a single image of the CFP channel. The background b(x)\begin{document}$ b(x)$\end{document} is traced by the light blue solid line in the bottom plot, to illustrate the slight x\begin{document}$ x$\end{document} dependence. To estimate and remove the background, in each image the average fluorescence across a 50x50 pixel box located 15 pixels above each mother cell was removed from the fluorescence measurement of each respective cell in that image. Note also that an empty trench produces a significant amount of fluorescence when compared to cell-containing trenches. This indicates that fluorescence originating from the media itself needs to be considered. This will be discussed in the next section. The fluorescence profile was created using the plot profile function in Fiji ImageJ. (B) With the background b(x)\begin{document}$ b(x)$\end{document} removed, it remains to correct for S(x)\begin{document}$ S(x)$\end{document}. We bin all of the fluorescence measurement of all cells and over all time according to pixel position x\begin{document}$ x$\end{document} in bins of size 50 pixels and take the average of each bin (blue dots). A single frame has a width of 2048 pixels. This gives an estimate of ⟨IFP+Iauto+Imedia⟩×S(x)\begin{document}$ \langle I^{FP}+I^{auto}+I^{media}\rangle\times S(x)$\end{document}, with deviations resulting from finite sampling. The binned averages are fit using the least squares method with a third-degree polynomial (solid orange line). The uneven illumination gain function S(x)\begin{document}$ S(x)$\end{document} is corrected by multiplying all the fluorescence measurements with the reciprocal of the fitted polynomial. Data shown is from the strain 6 system from Appendix 1—figure 18.

caption.title: Estimating confidence intervals for normalized covariance measurements using two methods.
caption.p: (A) Imaging error corrections and the normalized covariance are computed 100 times for 100 bootstrap samples of the experimental data. The final normalized covariance is given as the average over the samples, with confidence intervals given by two times the standard deviation. (B) The data is divided into Nsamples=min(M,10)\begin{document}$N_{samples} = \text{min}(M, 10)$\end{document} disjoint sample sets, where M is the number of cells that lost the plasmid. Most experiments produced M>10\begin{document}$M\gt10$\end{document}, but a few produced M<10\begin{document}$M\lt10$\end{document} (with a minimum of 7). Imaging error corrections and the normalized covariance are computed for each sample. The final normalized covariance is given by the average over the Nsamples\begin{document}$N_{samples}$\end{document} samples, with confidence intervals given by two times the standard error of the mean.

sec.p: General rates for four component systemx→rx+x+1y→ry+y+1z→rz+z+1w→rw+w+1x→rx−x−1y→ry−y−1z→rz−z−1w→rw−w−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} x \xrightarrow{r_x^+} x+1 \qquad y \xrightarrow{r_y^+} y+1 \qquad z \xrightarrow{r_z^+} z+1 \qquad w \xrightarrow{r_w^+} w+1 \\[10pt] x \xrightarrow{r_x^-} x-1 \qquad y \xrightarrow{r_y^-} y-1 \qquad z \xrightarrow{r_z^-} z-1 \qquad w \xrightarrow{r_w^-} w-1 \\ \end{array}$$\end{document}

caption.title: Simulated birth-death processes in growing and dividing cells.
caption.p: Additional details in Section 11. Top box shows a general four-component birth-death process. Below the box shows the respective rates for the 10 processes simulated. For each process, three different single-cell volume trajectories V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document} were simulated according to the Materials and methods of the main text, and the rate parameters shown above were varied randomly multiple times. In processes 1–3, 8, and 9, λ was picked randomly from the set {10, 100, 1000}, whereas in processes 4, 5, and 7, it was picked randomly from the set {1,10, 100}. The parameter δ is set to 0.01 throughout to avoid divisions by 0. In processes 4, 5, 7, and 9, α is respectively set to (2, 0.1, 1),(2, 0.5, 0.1), (2, 1, 0.5), (1, 2, 0.5) for all simulations with respective volume dynamics (1, 2, 3). For example, in system 4 with volume dynamics 2, α = 0.1. All other parameters, namely,β,βz,βw,λz,λw,K,A,B,C,ω\begin{document}$\beta, \beta_{z}, \beta_{w}, \lambda_{z}, \lambda_{w}, K, A, B, C, \omega$\end{document} were picked randomly from the set {0.1, 1, 10}. In all simulations, the average division time is set to 1. Simulations were performed using the Gillespie algorithm, with adjustments to account for time-dependent rates, as described in Section 14.

sec.title: A. Bacterial strains and growth conditions
sec.p: A complete list of the synthetic circuits can be found in Appendix 1—figures 17–20 . A complete list of strains is in Appendix 1—table 2.

The MG1655 E. coli strain used (SKA360 from Aoki et al., 2019) for the microfluidic experiments with circuits 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, and 11 had gene attB::lacYA177C and the following deletions: ΔaraCBAD, ΔlacIZYA, ΔaraE, ΔaraFGH, ΔrhaSRT, and ΔrhaBADM. The strain used for circuit 5 was identical with an added attn7::PRNA1-mCherry-mKate2-hybrid chromosomal gene. This last strain was also used in Appendix 1—figure 10 for the strain with no plasmid. The MG1655 E. coli strain used (NDL162 from Luro et al., 2020) for the microfluidic experiments with circuits 12, 14, and 15 had chromosomal gene glmS::PRNA1-mCherry-mKate2-hybrid and a motility deletion ΔmotA. The strain used for circuit 13 was identical with the additional ΔrpoS::FRT-Kan-frt. The strain used for circuit 4 was identical to NDL162 but without the chromosomal gene glmS::PRNA1-mCherry-mKate2-hybrid.

The standard heat shock procedure was used to transform plasmid DNA into chemically competent E. coli. During cloning procedures, E. coli strains were grown in LB medium (1% tryptone, 0.5% yeast extract, 1NaCl) with aeration at 250 rpm or LB agar plates at 37°C with appropriate antibiotics at standard concentrations: Ampicillin 100 μg/ml (Amp) and Kanamycin 50 μg/ml (Kan) (antibiotics and LB medium sourced from Fisher Scientific).

Prior to a mother machine experiment, cells were grown overnight in LB medium with appropriate antibiotics from glycerol stocks. At ∼3-4 hr prior to the experiment start time, the overnight cultures were diluted 1:100 in imaging media consisting of M9 salts, 10% (v/v) LB, 0.2% (w/v) glucose, 2 mM MgSO4, 0.1 mM CaCl2, 1.5 μM thiamine hydrochloride and 0.85 g/L Pluronic F-108 (Sigma Aldrich, surfactant to prevent cells sticking to the surface of a microfluidic device). For experiments with circuits 2, 7, 8, and 9 in which IPTG is used, the respective concentrations of IPTG shown in Appendix 1—figures 17–19 are added to the imaging media given to the cells at this point and throughout the remainder of the experiment.

sec.title: B. Plasmid construction
sec.p: A complete list of plasmids can be found in Appendix 1—table 2. Snapgene files are available on GitHub. Primers and PCR fragments are labeled in the Snapgene files.

Plasmids on the left side of Appendix 1—figures 17–20 were constructed using Gibson assembly (NEBuilder HiFi DNA Assembly Master Mix, NEB, MA, USA). Reactions were performed according to the manufacturers protocols, with Gibson assembly reactions incubated for 15 min at 50°C.

Primers were ordered from Thermo Fisher Scientific and PCR were performed with Accuprime Pfx (Thermo Fisher) or Phusion polymerase (New England BioLabs) according to manufacturers protocols. All plasmids were verified by DNA sequencing, either Sanger sequencing by Quintara Biosciences (MA, USA) or whole plasmid nanopore sequencing with Plasmidsaurus certified by Oxford Nanopore Technologies.

Various fragments from plasmids built in Potvin-Trottier et al., 2016 were amplified by PCR with the ordered primers. Most notably is pLPT119, which formed the backbone for all the plasmid constructs. It consists of the repressilator with no degradation tags on the lacI, cI, and tetR genes (Potvin-Trottier et al., 2016).

To assemble pEJS1 and pEJS10 by phusion reaction, two fragments were amplified from pLPT119 and made up the three repressors from the repressilator, SCFP3A with PLlacO-1 promoter was amplified from pLPT107, and mVenus NB was amplified from pTP85.

To assemble pEJS3 and pEJS4, SCFP3A with PLlacO-1 promoter was amplified from pLPT107, mCherry-mKate2-hybrid with PLtetO-1 promoter was amplified from pLPT27, mVenus fusion from pEJ1, and repressilator fragments were amplified from pLPT119.

To assemble pEJS5, SCFP3A with PLlacO-1 promoter was amplified from pLPT107, mCherry-mKate2-hybrid with PRNA1 promoter was amplified from pLPT26, mVenus fusion from pEJS1, and repressilator fragments were amplified from pLPT119.

For the experiment shown in Figure 4D, we used a pSC101 plasmid with Kanamycin resistance and a gfpmut2 reporter gene with gadX promoter taken from Zaslaver et al., 2006 (ordered from the E. coli Promoter Collection from Horizon Discovery).

The tetR-yfp fusion was made by removing the stop codon from the tetR sequence and replacing it with a short linker sequence followed by the mVenus NB sequence. The first nucleotide from the mVenus NB start codon is not added. The linker sequence is GGGTCTGACATCCTCGAGT.
All repressilator gene sequences and fluorescent protein sequences are followed by transcription terminator T1 from the E. coli rrnB gene.

sec.title: 4. Class of systems
sec.p: We consider an arbitrarily complex time-continuous Markov chain of birth-death processes with unspecified reaction rates, corresponding to a biochemical reaction network in a cell. The state of the system at a given moment in time is given by the numbers z={zk}\begin{document}$\mathbf{z} = \{z_{k}\}$\end{document}, consisting of the abundances of all the chemical species in the cell, and all stochastic processes that influence their chemical reaction rates. The dynamics of the system varies stochastically according to unspecified reaction rates:(4.1)z→Wi(z)z+difori=1,2,3…,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathbf{z} \xrightarrow[]{\quad W_{i}(\mathbf{z}) \quad } \mathbf{z} + \mathbf{d}_{i} \quad \text{for} \quad i = 1, 2, 3\dots ,$$\end{document}

where Wi(z)\begin{document}$W_{i}(\mathbf{z})$\end{document} is the probability per unit time that the i-th reaction occurs, and di\begin{document}$\mathbf{d}_{i}$\end{document} is the step size of the i-th reaction.

The reaction rate functions Wi(z)\begin{document}$W_{i}(\mathbf{z})$\end{document} can depend on all the system variables or on a subset of them. The Markov chain can be drawn as a network, where nodes correspond to the components {zk}\begin{document}$\{z_{k}\}$\end{document}, and directional links correspond to explicit parameter dependencies in the rates Wi(z)\begin{document}$W_{i}(\mathbf{z})$\end{document}. For instance, if the component zn\begin{document}$z_{n}$\end{document} ever changes with a reaction rate that depends explicitly on zm\begin{document}$z_{m}$\end{document}, then an arrow is drawn from the zm\begin{document}$z_{m}$\end{document} node to the zn\begin{document}$z_{n}$\end{document} node, see Appendix 1—figure 21A.

Note that because molecular abundances cannot be negative, any biochemical system must have the property that the propensity of a reaction must be equal to zero when the system is in a state in which an occurrence of that reaction would take one of the abundances to negative numbers. Stochastic networks that do not have this property cannot correspond to biochemical reaction networks. As a result, the abundances {zk}\begin{document}$\{z_{k}\}$\end{document} are bounded to be non-negative through reaction rate dependencies. For example, if P(z,t)\begin{document}$P(\mathbf{z}, t)$\end{document} and zk\begin{document}$z_{k}$\end{document} correspond to the abundance of molecular species Zj\begin{document}$Z_{j}$\end{document} and Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} respectively which undergo the following conversion reaction (zj,zk)→Wi(z)(zj−1,zk+1)\begin{document}$(z_{j}, z_{k})\xrightarrow[]{\quad W_{i}(\mathbf{z}) \quad } (z_{j} - 1, z_{k} + 1)$\end{document}, then the transition probability function Wi\begin{document}$W_i$\end{document} must have an explicit zi\begin{document}$z_i$\end{document} dependence in that the following must be satisfied: Wi(z)=0\begin{document}$W_{i}(\mathbf{z}) = 0$\end{document} when zj=0\begin{document}$z_{j} = 0$\end{document}. Even in the particular case where the conversion rate is approximately independent of the educt concentration when the latter is non-zero, the reaction cannot physically occur when zj=0\begin{document}$z_{j} = 0$\end{document}, and so Wi\begin{document}$W_{i}$\end{document} must have an explicit zi\begin{document}$z_{i}$\end{document} dependence.

The system probability distribution P(z,t)\begin{document}$P(\mathbf{z}, t)$\end{document} for this network evolves according to the chemical master equation (Van Kampen, 1992; Lestas et al., 2008):(4.2)ddtP(z,t)=∑k[Wk(z−dk)P(z−dk,t)−Wk(z)P(z,t)].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d}{dt}P(\mathbf{z},t) = \sum_{k}\left[W_{k}(\mathbf{z} - \mathbf{d}_{k})P(\mathbf{z} - \mathbf{d}_{k},t) - W_{k}(\mathbf{z})P(\mathbf{z},t)\right] . $$\end{document}
Time evolution equations for the moments ⟨ukn⟩\begin{document}$\langle u_{k}^{n} \rangle$\end{document} of each component follow directly from the master equation .

caption.title: Definition of the class of systems modeling a gene and its passive reporter.
caption.p: (A) An example Markov chain with the state of the system given by z=(z1,z2,z3,z4)\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}=(z_{1},z_{2},z_{3},z_{4})$\end{document}. Nodes correspond to system variables, whereas arrows correspond to reaction rate dependencies. For instance, if z2\begin{document}$z_{2}$\end{document} changes under any transition with a reaction rate that depends explicitly on z1\begin{document}$ z_{1}$\end{document}, then we draw an arrow from z1\begin{document}$z_{1}$\end{document} to z2\begin{document}$z_{2}$\end{document}. We say that a variable affects another variable if a path can be drawn in the network topology from the first variable to the second. (B) We consider all stochastic processes in which two cellular components, X and Y, are made with an identical, but unspecified, rate. This rate can depend in any way on a cloud of unknown time-varying components z\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}$\end{document}, which in turn can depend in arbitrary ways on the number of X and Y molecules, denoted by x and y. The birth and death reactions of X and Y in Equations 4.3; 4.4 are the only specified parts within this arbitrarily large network. We define two disjoint sets that make up all the unspecified components in the networks. The variables affected by X or Y, denoted by zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} are all the components in the network that X or Y affects. All other components in the system are denoted by zaffc\begin{document}$ \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}, which can affect the components affected by X in an arbitrary way.

sec.title: A. mRNA reporters
sec.p: We let X correspond to the transcript of a gene of interest, with x\begin{document}$ x$\end{document} corresponding to the number of X molecules. Functional interactions in this network are specified by the dependencies of the reaction rates in the network. We say that X affects another component Z if a path can be drawn from X to Z in the topology of the network, see Appendix 1—figure 21A. The set of all components in the network that are affected by X or Y is denoted by zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}. All other components in the cell are denoted as zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}, see Appendix 1—figure 21B. We let the X number dynamics be described by a stochastic birth-death process, with production and degradation reactions of X to be given by(4.3)x→R(zaff,zaffc)x+1x→xβ(zaffc)x−1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x \xrightarrow[]{R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} x+1\qquad x \xrightarrow[]{\; \; x\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}) \; \;} x-1 , $$\end{document}

where the production rate R\begin{document}$ R$\end{document} can depend in any way on the sets of unspecified components zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} and zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}, and the degradation rate β\begin{document}$ \beta$\end{document} can depend in any way on all components not affected by X or Y, as long as any possible realization of βt\begin{document}$\beta_{t}$\end{document} does not decay to zero over time (i.e., ⟨β⟩t=limT→∞1T∫0Tβtdt>0\begin{document}$\langle\beta\rangle_{t}=\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}\beta_{t}dt \gt 0$\end{document}). If X is the transcript of geneX, then the rate R\begin{document}$ R$\end{document} corresponds production rate corresponds to the transcription rate of geneX.

We next introduce into the system a passive reporter Y, engineered to read out the same signal as X that degrades with the same rate(4.4)y→αR(zaff,zaffc)y+1y→yβ(zaffc)y−1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle y \xrightarrow[]{\alpha R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} y+1\qquad y \xrightarrow[]{\; \; y\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}) \; \;} y-1 , $$\end{document}

where α\begin{document}$ \alpha$\end{document} is an arbitrary proportionality constant. We extend the definition of zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} to include all components affected by X or Y. These components can in turn depend in arbitrary ways on the number of X and Y molecules. The dynamics of all other cellular components in the cell thus remain unspecified, and the resulting dynamics need not be Markovian or ergodic in X and Y. Note that the sets of unknown components can include an unbounded number of nonphysical mock variables, which can model the different spatial compartments that X can find itself in as well as any complex history-dependent dynamics. We only specify that the total X abundance undergoes first-order degradation, where the degradation rate can depend in an arbitrary way on any of the variables not affected by X or Y.

sec.title: B. Fluorescent protein reporters
sec.p: We can also consider a different class of systems in which X denotes the protein of a gene of interest that is fused to a fluorescent protein. This fluorescent protein must undergo a maturation step before it can fluoresce. We denote the immature fluorescent protein as X, and the transcript for this protein as Mx\begin{document}$M_{x}$\end{document}. The mRNA abundances are described by the following stochastic birth-death processes modeling transcription and mRNA degradation(4.5)mx→R(zaff,zaffc)mx+1mx→mxβ(zaffc)mx−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle m_{x} \xrightarrow[]{R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} m_{x}+1\qquad m_{x} \xrightarrow[]{\; \; m_{x}\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}) \; \;} m_{x}-1 $$\end{document}

The ‘dark’ fluorescent proteins Xd are translated from the mRNA and then mature into ‘bright’ fluorescent proteins X, which are then degraded:(4.6)xd→λ(zaffc)mxxd+1(xd,x)→xd/τmat(xd−1,x+1)x→xβp(zaffc)x−1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x_{d} \xrightarrow[]{ \lambda(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})m_{x} } x_{d}+1\qquad (x_{d}, x) \xrightarrow[]{x_{d}/\tau_{mat}} (x_{d} - 1, x + 1) \qquad x \xrightarrow[]{x \beta_{p}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} x - 1 , $$\end{document}

where λ(zaffc)\begin{document}$\lambda(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})$\end{document} is an unspecified translation rate, τmat\begin{document}$\tau_{mat}$\end{document} is the average maturation time, and βp(zaffc)\begin{document}$\beta_{p}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})$\end{document} is an unspecified protein degradation factor. The translation rate λ\begin{document}$ \lambda$\end{document} and degradation rate βp\begin{document}$\beta_{p}$\end{document} can fluctuate and can depend in arbitrary ways on all the components not affected by X or Mx\begin{document}$ M_{x}$\end{document} or Y or My\begin{document}$M_{y}$\end{document}. We assume that any possible realization of βp\begin{document}$ \beta_{p}$\end{document} does not decay to zero over time (i.e. ⟨βp⟩t=limT→∞1T∫0Tβp,tdt>0\begin{document}$ \langle\beta_{p}\rangle_{t}=\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}\beta_{p,t }dt \gt 0$\end{document}). The fluorescent proteins are assumed to undergo first-order maturation. In Balleza et al., 2018, the authors show that approximately a third of a large set of common fluorescent proteins undergo first-order maturation kinetics in bacteria.

We next introduce into the system a passive reporter Y corresponding to a second fluorescent protein reading out the same transcription rate:(4.7)my→αR(zaff,zaffc)my+1my→myβ(zaffc)my−1yd→αpλ(zaffc)myyd+1(yd,y)→yd/τmat(yd−1,y+1)y→yβp(zaffc)y−1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}m_{y} \xrightarrow[]{\alpha R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} m_{y}+1 \qquad m_{y} \xrightarrow[]{\; \; m_{y}\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}) \; \;} m_{y}-1 \\ y_{d} \xrightarrow[]{ \alpha_{p}\lambda(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})m_{y} } y_{d}+1\qquad (y_{d}, y) \xrightarrow[]{y_{d}/\tau_{mat}} (y_{d} - 1, y + 1) \qquad y \xrightarrow[]{y \beta_{p}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} y - 1 , \end{array}$$\end{document}

where the transcription and translation rates are proportional to those of geneX with unknown proportionality constants α\begin{document}$ \alpha$\end{document} and αp\begin{document}$ \alpha_{p}$\end{document}. The average maturation and degradation times are equal to those of X.

sec.title: 5. The invariant relation — Derivation of Equation 2
sec.p: Definition 1. A co-transition event is a transition event in the system where two or more components change simultaneously. That is, a reaction where the step size d has more than one vector component.

An example would be a conversion event, where a chemical species zm\begin{document}$z_{m}$\end{document} converts to another chemical species zn\begin{document}$z_{n}$\end{document}(zm,zn)→W(zm)(zm−1,zn+1)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle (z_m,\, z_n) \xrightarrow{W(z_m)} (z_m - 1,\, z_n + 1) $$\end{document}

According to our framework, an arrow would be drawn from zm\begin{document}$ z_{m}$\end{document} to zn\begin{document}$ z_{n}$\end{document} in the network if the above reaction was part of the system. Another example would be two molecules zm\begin{document}$z_{m}$\end{document}, zn\begin{document}$z_{n}$\end{document} that bind to form a complex zl\begin{document}$ z_{l}$\end{document}(zm,zn,zl)→W(zm,zn)(zm−1,zn−1,zl+1).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle (z_m, z_n, z_l) \xrightarrow{W(z_m, z_n)} (z_m - 1, z_n - 1, z_l + 1).$$\end{document}

If the above reaction was part of the system, an arrow would be drawn from zm\begin{document}$ z_{m}$\end{document} to zn\begin{document}$ z_{n}$\end{document}, from zn\begin{document}$ z_{n}$\end{document} to zm\begin{document}$ z_{m}$\end{document}, and from both zm\begin{document}$ z_{m}$\end{document}, zn\begin{document}$ z_{n}$\end{document} to zl\begin{document}$ z_{l}$\end{document}.

In order to derive Equation 2, we need to assume that no components in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} are part of a co-transition event with any variable in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}. We thus begin by proving the following lemma.

Lemma 1. Let Zk be a component that is not affected by X or Y. For any network of the class in Appendix 1—figure 21B (Equations 4.3; 4.4), there exists another network with the exact same dynamics in X, Y, and Zk, but where no components in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} are part of a co-transition event with any component in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}.

Proof of Lemma 1. Let the following co-transition reaction be part of the system, where {ak}\begin{document}$\{a_{k}\}$\end{document} are variables in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} and {bk}\begin{document}$\{b_{k}\}$\end{document} are variables in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}(5.1)(a,b)→W(b)(a+da,b+db).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle (\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}) \xrightarrow{W(\mathbf{b})} (\mathbf{a} + \mathbf{d}_a, \mathbf{b} + \mathbf{d}_b). $$\end{document}

By definition of zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} and zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}, the reaction rate W\begin{document}$ W$\end{document} in the above reaction cannot depend on the variables {ak}\begin{document}$\{a_{k}\}$\end{document}. However, because a is part of zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}, the {ak}\begin{document}$\{a_{k}\}$\end{document} variables must be affected by X or Y. Therefore, there must exist one or more reactions, labeled with i∈{1,2,…}\begin{document}$i\in\{1,2,\dots\}$\end{document}, in the system, that change a with reaction rates that depend on the variables affected by X or Y(5.2)a→Wi(zaff,zaffc)a+difori=1,2,…\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathbf{a} \xrightarrow[]{ W_{i}\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c} \right)} \mathbf{a} + \mathbf{d}_{i} \quad \text{for} \quad i = 1,2,\dots $$\end{document}

Note that the above reactions cannot make changes to b; otherwise, the {bk}\begin{document}$\{b_{k}\}$\end{document} variables would not be in the variables not affected by X or Y. We now consider an exact copy of the whole system z and the system reactions, with the change that the a variables are decomposed into two sets of mock variables. Specifically, we define the variables {akint}\begin{document}$\{a^{int}_{k}\}$\end{document} and {akb}\begin{document}$\{a^{b}_{k}\}$\end{document} that undergo the following reactions(ab,b)→W(b)(ab+da,b+db)aint→Wi(zaff,zaffc)aint+difori=1,2,…,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle (\mathbf{a}^{b},\; \mathbf{b}) & \xrightarrow{W (\mathbf{b}) \quad \; \;} \left(\mathbf{a}^{b} + \mathbf{d}_{a},\; \mathbf{b} + \mathbf{d}_{b} \right) \\[5pt] \mathbf{a}^{int} & \xrightarrow{ W_{i}\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c} \right)} \mathbf{a}^{int} + \mathbf{d}_{i} \quad \text{for} \quad i = 1,2,\dots, $$\end{document}

which correspond to the reactions in Equations 5.1; 5.2. We replace all the explicit a dependencies in the reaction rates of the system with aint+ab\begin{document}$\mathbf{a}^{int}+\mathbf{a}^{b}$\end{document}. As a result, all the reactions that depended on a are unchanged, but now we can put the ab\begin{document}$\mathbf{a}^{b}$\end{document} variables in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}, and we can put the aint\begin{document}$\mathbf{a}^{int}$\end{document} variables in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}. We are left with a system where the aint\begin{document}$\mathbf{a}^{int}$\end{document} are not part of a co-transition event with variables in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}, and the dynamics of X and Y remain unchanged. Moreover, none of the reaction rates that govern the dynamics of any component in the original zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} have been altered, meaning the dynamics of Zk remain unchanged. Such a decomposition can be done for any co-transition reaction that involves components from zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} and zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}.

We now let Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} correspond to another component of interest in the system, as a continuous-time Markov process. It can be any stochastic process that can be measured, like the abundance of a molecular species in the network, the size of the cell, or any parameter that can influence the reaction rates of the system.

Theorem 1. Let Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} be a component in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document}. If the averages ⟨xt⟩\begin{document}$\langle x_{t}\rangle$\end{document}, ⟨yt⟩\begin{document}$\langle y_{t}\rangle$\end{document} and the covariances Cov(xt,zk,t)\begin{document}$\text{Cov}(x_{t},z_{k,t})$\end{document}, Cov(xt,zk,t)\begin{document}$\text{Cov}(x_{t},z_{k,t})$\end{document} over the ensemble have reached a stationary state (i.e. they have become constant over time), then ηxzk=ηyzk\begin{document}$\eta_{xz_{k}}=\eta_{yz_{k}}$\end{document}.

Proof of Theorem 1. We condition on the components not affected by X or Y, zaffc[−∞,t]\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]$\end{document}. This corresponds to a hypothetical system where all the variables in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} become deterministic time-varying signals {zk(t)}\begin{document}$\{z_{k}(t)\}$\end{document}. The reactions governing X and Y in the conditional system become(5.3)x→R(zaff,t)x+1y→αR(zaff,t)y+1x→xβ(t)x−1y→yβ(t)y−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{cc} x \xrightarrow{R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\, t)} x + 1 & y \xrightarrow{\alpha R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\, t)} y + 1 \\[1.5em] x \xrightarrow{x\beta(t)} x - 1 & y \xrightarrow{y\beta(t)} y - 1 \end{array}$$\end{document}

where R(zaff,t)=R(zaff,zaffc(t))\begin{document}$R\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},t\right)=R\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}(t)\right)$\end{document} and β(t)=β(zaffc(t))\begin{document}$\beta(t)=\beta\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}(t)\right)$\end{document} now have an explicit time dependence from the conditioned history zaffc[−∞,t]\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]$\end{document}. We let A\begin{document}$ A$\end{document} be the set of all integers k such that the k-th reaction in Equation 4.1 leads to a change in at least one of the components in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}. In the conditional probability space, the components affected in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} follow the following reactions(5.4)zaff→Wk(zaff,t)zaff+dk∀k∈A,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}} \xrightarrow[]{\quad W_{k}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; t) \quad } \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}} + \mathbf{d}_{k} \quad \forall k \in A , $$\end{document}

where Wk(zaff,t)=Wk(zaff,zaffc(t))\begin{document}$W_{k}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\;t)=W_{k}\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}(t)\right)$\end{document} now has an explicit time dependence from the conditioned history of the variables not affected by X or Y. Note that if some components in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} were part of a co-transition event with components in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document}, then Equations 5.3; 5.4 would not hold. This is because conditioning on the history of those extrinsic variables effectively conditions on those birth events in zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} that are caused by those co-transitions. However, from Lemma 1, we can always work with another network in which there are no such co-transition events, and where the dynamics of X and Y remain unchanged.

This conditional system follows the following master equationddtP(x,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])=∑k∈A[Wk(zaff−dk,t)P(x,y,zaff−dk,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])−Wk(zaff,t)P(x,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])]+R(x−1,y,zaff,t)P(x−1,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])−R(x,y,zaff,t)P(x,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])+αR(x,y−1,zaff,t)P(x,y−1,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])−αR(x,y,zaff,t)P(x,y,zaff;t∣zaffc[−∞,t])+(x+1)β(t)P(x+1,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])−xβ(t)P(x,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])+(y+1)β(t)P(x,y+1,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t])−yβ(t)P(x,y,zaff,t∣zaffc[−∞,t]).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} \frac{d}{d t} & P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)= \\ & \quad \sum_{k \in A}\left[W_k\left(\mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}-\mathbf{d}_k, t\right) P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}-\mathbf{d}_k, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)-W_k\left(\mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t\right) P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)\right] \\ & \quad+R\left(x-1, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t\right) P\left(x-1, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)-R\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t\right) P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right) \\ & \quad+\alpha R\left(x, y-1, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t\right) P\left(x, y-1, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)-\alpha R\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t\right) P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}} ; t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right) \\ & \quad+(x+1) \beta(t) P\left(x+1, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)-x \beta(t) P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right) \\ & \quad+(y+1) \beta(t) P\left(x, y+1, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right)-y \beta(t) P\left(x, y, \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}, t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\mathrm{aff}}^c[-\infty, t]\right). \end{array}$$\end{document}

We consider the averages of X and Y conditioned on the upstream history, x¯(t)=E[xt|zaffc[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{x}(t)=E\left[x_{t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document} and y¯(t)=E[yt|zaffc[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{y}(t)=E\left[y_{t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document}, where xt\begin{document}$x_{t}$\end{document} and yt\begin{document}$y_{t}$\end{document} are the X and Y abundances at time t. From the above master equation, the time-evolution for these first moments can be derived (Joly-Smith et al., 2021; Hilfinger and Paulsson, 2011)(5.5)dx¯dt=R¯(t)−x¯β¯(t)&dy¯dt=αR¯(t)−y¯β¯(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\bar{x}}{dt} = \bar{R}(t) - \bar{x} \bar{\beta}(t) \quad \& \quad \frac{d\bar{y}}{dt} = \alpha \bar{R}(t) - \bar{y} \bar{\beta}(t),$$\end{document}

where R¯(t)=E[R(xt,yt,zaff,t)|z affc[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{R}(t)=E\left[R(x_{t},y_{t},\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},t)|\mathbf{z}_{\text{ aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document} and β¯(t)=E[β(zaffc)|zaff c[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{\beta}(t)=E\left[\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff }}^{c}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document} are the average production and degradation rates conditioned on the history of the variables not affected by X or Y. Note that β¯(t)=E[β(zaffc)|zaff c[−∞,t]]=β(zaffc(t))=β(t)\begin{document}$\bar{\beta}(t)=E\left[\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff }}^{c}[-\infty,t]\right]=\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}(t))=\beta(t)$\end{document}, because the time trajectory of zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} is set through the conditioning on the upstream history. We can then take the expectation of x¯\begin{document}$ \bar{x}$\end{document} over all possible histories of zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} to get(5.6)E[x¯(t)]histories=E[E[xt∣zaffc[−∞,t]]]histories=⟨xt⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E[\bar{x}(t)]_{\text{histories}} = E\left[ E\left[ x_t\mid \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty, t] \right] \right]_{\text{histories}} = \langle x_t \rangle, $$\end{document}

which follows from the law of total expectation. We now let Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} correspond to any component in the network that is not affected by X or Y. It can be a molecular abundance, concentration, or another stochastic cellular variable like the growth rate of the cell. It follows that(5.7)E[x¯(t)zk(t)]histories=E[E[xt∣zaff c[−∞,t]]⋅E[zk,t∣zaff c[−∞,t]]]histories =E[E[xtzk,t∣zaff c[−∞,t]]]histories =⟨xtzk,t⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E\left[\bar{x}(t) z_k(t)\right]_{\text{histories}} & =E\left[E\left[x_t \mid \mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c[-\infty, t]\right] \cdot E\left[z_{k, t} \mid \mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c[-\infty, t]\right]\right]_{\text{histories }} \\ &=E\left[E\left[x_t z_{k, t} \mid \mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c[-\infty, t]\right]\right]_{\text{histories }}=\left\langle x_t z_{k, t}\right\rangle ,$$\end{document}

where z¯k(t)=E[zk,t|zaffc[−∞,t]]=zk(t)\begin{document}$ \bar{z}_{k}(t)=E\left[z_{k,t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\right]=z_ {k}(t)$\end{document}, where the last step comes from the fact that the time trajectory of zk\begin{document}$z_{k}$\end{document} is set through the conditioning of the upstream histories. Intuitively, Equation 5.8 says that when X does not affect Zk\begin{document}$ Z_{k}$\end{document}, the stochastic fluctuations of X average out when taking the covariance between X and Zk\begin{document}$ Z_{k}$\end{document}. Strikingly, this is independent of any type of feedback that X may impose through interactions in the cloud of components z(t)\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}(t)$\end{document}. As a result, the same should hold for Y, and since y¯(t)\begin{document}$\bar{y}(t)$\end{document} is governed by the same differential equation as x¯\begin{document}$\bar{x}$\end{document}, the intrinsic fluctuations that differentiate X and Y will average out when taking the covariances with Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}.

That is, dividing the right equation in Equation 5.5 with α, we write the general solution for x¯(t)\begin{document}$ \bar{x}(t)$\end{document} and y¯(t)/α\begin{document}$ \bar{y}(t)/\alpha$\end{document}, and find(5.9)x¯(t)=x¯(0)e−∫0tβ(u)du+∫0te−(∫0tβ(u)du−∫0t′β(v)dv)R(t′)dt′\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{x}(t) = \bar{x}(0)e^{-\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du} + \int_{0}^{t}e^{-\left(\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du - \int_{0}^{t'}\beta(v)dv\right)}R(t')dt'$$\end{document}(5.10)y¯(t)/α=y¯(0)e−∫0tβ(u)du/α+∫0te−(∫0tβ(u)du−∫0t′β(v)dv)R(t′)dt′\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{y}(t)/\alpha = \bar{y}(0)e^{-\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du}/\alpha + \int_{0}^{t}e^{-\left(\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du - \int_{0}^{t'}\beta(v)dv\right)}R(t')dt'$$\end{document}

Taking the average over all histories and subtracting the equations we have(5.11)E[x¯(t)]histories−E[y¯(t)]histories=E[(x¯(0)−y¯(0)/α)e−∫0tβ(u)du]histories⇒⟨xt⟩−⟨yt⟩/α=E[(x¯(0)−y¯(0)/α)e−∫0tβ(u)du]histories,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E[\bar{x}(t)]_{\text{histories}} - E[\bar{y}(t)]_{\text{histories}} & = E\left[\left(\bar{x}(0) - \bar{y}(0)/\alpha \right)e^{-\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du}\right]_{\text{histories}} \nonumber \\ \Rightarrow \langle x_{t} \rangle - \langle y_{t} \rangle \big/\alpha & = E\left[\left(\bar{x}(0) - \bar{y}(0)/\alpha \right)e^{-\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du}\right]_{\text{histories}}, $$\end{document}

where in the second step we used Equation 5.6 which also holds for y\begin{document}$ y$\end{document} by symmetry. We now invoke the requirement that the averages ⟨xt⟩\begin{document}$\langle x_{t}\rangle$\end{document} and ⟨yt⟩\begin{document}$\langle y_{t}\rangle$\end{document} are stationary, meaning they are constant over time. In that case, ⟨xt⟩−⟨yt⟩/α\begin{document}$\langle x_{t}\rangle-\langle y_{t}\rangle/\alpha$\end{document} is constant over time, and so(5.12)⟨xt⟩−⟨yt⟩/α=limt→∞(⟨xt⟩−⟨yt⟩/α).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{t} \rangle - \langle y_{t} \rangle/\alpha = \lim_{t\to \infty}\left(\langle x_{t} \rangle - \langle y_{t} \rangle/\alpha \right).$$\end{document}

Substituting Equation 5.11, we thus have(5.13)⟨xt⟩−⟨yt⟩/α=E[(x¯(0)−y¯(0)/α)e−∫0∞β(u)du]histories.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{t} \rangle - \langle y_{t} \rangle/\alpha = E\left[\left(\bar{x}(0) - \bar{y}(0)/\alpha \right)e^{-\int_{0}^{\infty} \beta(u)du}\right]_{\text{histories}}. $$\end{document}

Now, we must have ∫0∞β(u)du→∞\begin{document}$ \int_{0}^{\infty}\beta(u)du\to\infty$\end{document} when ⟨β⟩t=limT→∞1T∫0Tβ(u)du>0\begin{document}$\langle\beta\rangle_{t}=\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}\beta(u)du \gt 0$\end{document}. Therefore, the right-hand side of Equation 5.13 becomes 0:(5.14)⟨xt⟩−⟨yt⟩/α=E[(x¯(0)−y¯(0)/α)e−∫0∞β(u)du]histories=0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{t} \rangle - \langle y_{t} \rangle/\alpha = E\left[\left(\bar{x}(0) - \bar{y}(0)/\alpha \right)e^{-\int_{0}^{\infty} \beta(u)du}\right]_{\text{histories}} = 0, $$\end{document}

Similarly, we now multiply Equations 5.10; 5.9 with zk(t)\begin{document}$z_{k}(t)$\end{document}, average over all histories, and subtract to obtain(5.15)llE[x¯(t)zk(t)]histories−E[y¯(t)zk(t)]histories=E[(x¯(0)−y¯(0)/α)zk(t)e−∫0tβ(u)du]histories⇒⟨xtzk,t⟩−⟨ytzk,t⟩/α=E[(x¯(0)−y¯(0)/α)zk(t)e−∫0tβ(u)du]histories=0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {ll} E[\bar{x}(t)z_{k}(t)]_{\text{histories}} - E[\bar{y}(t)z_{k}(t)]_{\text{histories}} & = E\left[\left(\bar{x}(0) - \bar{y}(0)/\alpha \right)z_{k}(t)e^{-\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du}\right]_{\text{histories}} \nonumber \\ \Rightarrow \langle x_{t}z_{k,t} \rangle - \langle y_{t}z_{k,t} \rangle/\alpha & = E\left[\left(\bar{x}(0) - \bar{y}(0)/\alpha \right)z_{k}(t)e^{-\int_{0}^{t}\beta(u)du}\right]_{\text{histories}} = 0, $$\end{document}

where in the second step we used Equation 5.7 which also holds for y by symmetry. The last step follows when ⟨xtzk,t⟩\begin{document}$\langle x_{t}z_{k,t}\rangle$\end{document} and ⟨ytzk,t⟩\begin{document}$\langle y_{t}z_{k,t}\rangle$\end{document} have reached stationarity and are constant over time, along with ⟨β⟩t=limT→∞1T∫0Tβ(u)du>0\begin{document}$\langle\beta\rangle_{t}=\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}\beta(u)du \gt 0$\end{document}.

It then follows from Equations 5.14; 5.15 that(5.16)⟨x⟩=⟨y⟩/α&Cov(x,zk)=Cov(y,zk)/α.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x \rangle = \langle y \rangle/\alpha \quad \& \quad \text{Cov}(x,z_{k}) = \text{Cov}(y,z_{k})/\alpha.$$\end{document}

Dividing Cov(x,zk)\begin{document}$\text{Cov}(x,z_{k})$\end{document} by ⟨x⟩⟨z⟩\begin{document}$\langle x\rangle\langle z\rangle$\end{document}, and Cov(y,zk)/α\begin{document}$\text{Cov}(y,z_{k})/\alpha$\end{document} by ⟨y⟩⟨z⟩/α\begin{document}$\langle y\rangle\langle z\rangle/\alpha$\end{document}, we find ηxzk=ηyzk\begin{document}$\eta_{xz_{k}}=\eta_{yz_{k}}$\end{document}.

If the reporter Y is engineered to be passive (i.e., it does not affect components in the network), then a violation of Equation 2 would imply that X affects Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}. Otherwise, such a violation would imply that X or Y affect Zk\begin{document}$ Z_{k}$\end{document}.

Thus far, we assumed that all the components not affected by X or Y are part of a continuous-time Markov chain. This was in order to make a rigorous definition of causal interaction in our framework as a path in the topology of the transition rates. Alternatively, if we relax the requirement that the components not affected by X or Y be Markov chains (i.e. they can be a set of arbitrary stochastic processes), we can operationally define ‘no causal interaction from X or Y’ to mean that we can condition on the history of those stochastic processes and write down Equations 5.3; 5.4. We can then operationally define any violation of Equation 2 as a ‘causal interaction from X or Y’ to a stochastic process Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}.

sec.title: 6. Derivation of the invariant relation for fluorescent proteins
sec.p: The derivation follows analogously to the proof of Theorem 1. We condition on the history of the components not affected by X or Y, from which the following differential equations follow like those in Equation 5.5:(6.1)lldm¯xdt=R¯(t)−m¯xβ(t)&dm¯ydt=αR¯(t)−m¯yβ(t)dx¯ddt=λ(t)m¯x−x¯d/τmat&dy¯ddt=αpλ(t)m¯y−y¯d/τmatdx¯dt=x¯d/τmat−x¯βp(t)&dy¯dt=y¯d/τmat−y¯βp(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {ll} \frac{d \bar{m}_{x} }{dt} = \bar{R}(t) - \bar{m}_{x}\beta(t) \quad &\& \quad \frac{d \bar{m}_{y} }{dt} = \alpha \bar{R}(t) - \bar{m}_{y}\beta(t) \\[5pt] \frac{d \bar{x}_{d} }{dt} = \lambda(t) \bar{m}_{x} - \bar{x}_{d}/\tau_{mat} \quad &\& \quad \frac{d \bar{y}_{d} }{dt} = \alpha_{p} \lambda(t)\bar{m}_{y} - \bar{y}_{d}/\tau_{mat} \\[5pt] \frac{d \bar{x} }{dt} = \bar{x}_{d}/\tau_{mat} - \bar{x}\beta_{p}(t) \quad &\& \quad \frac{d \bar{y} }{dt} = \bar{y}_{d}/\tau_{mat} - \bar{y}\beta_{p}(t), $$\end{document}

where λ(t)=λ(zaffc(t))\begin{document}$ \lambda(t)=\lambda(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}(t))$\end{document} and βp(t)=βp(zaffc(t))\begin{document}$ \beta_{p}(t)=\beta_{p}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}(t))$\end{document} . When the degradation rates β\begin{document}$ \beta$\end{document}, βp\begin{document}$\beta_{p}$\end{document} do not decay to zero for any possible realization, and when the dual reporter ensemble averages and their covariances with Zk\begin{document}$ Z_{k}$\end{document} have reached a time-independent state, it follows from Equation 6.1 analogously to the derivation from Equation 5.5 to Equation 5.16 that ηxzk=ηyzk\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz_{k}}=\eta_{yz_{k}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: 7. The X and Y production rates can differ by certain types of fluctuations
sec.p: In Section 5, we assumed that the production rates of X and Y were proportional with an arbitrary proportionality constant. This requirement can be relaxed. Here, we show that the X and Y production rates can differ by certain types of fluctuations. We do this by introducing a cloud of components in the network that model fluctuations in the X or Y production rates that cause them to not be exactly the same.

In particular, consider the following class of systems(7.1)x→Rx(zaff ,zaff c)x+1y→Ry(zaff ,zaff c)y+1x→xβ(zaff c)x−1y→yβ(zaff c)y−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{cc} x \xrightarrow{R_x\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}, \mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c\right)} x+1 & y \xrightarrow{R_y\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}, \mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c\right)} y+1 \\ x \xrightarrow{x \beta\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c\right)} x-1 & y \xrightarrow{y \beta\left(\mathbf{z}_{\text {aff }}^c\right)} y-1 \end{array}$$\end{document}

where Rx\begin{document}$R_{x}$\end{document} and Ry\begin{document}$R_{y}$\end{document} are now different production rates for X and Y. Given a component Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} that is not affected by X or Y, we define the following two disjoint sets: A and B, see Appendix 1—figure 22. The set of cellular components A corresponds to all components that affect Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}, along with all components that affect the degradation rate of X and Y, along with the component of interest Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}. The set B corresponds to all components that are not affected by X or Y but that also do not affect Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}. Note that both sets together, A∪B\begin{document}$\mathbf{A}\cup\mathbf{B}$\end{document}, form the set of components not affected by X or Y (which we refer to as zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} in previous sections). The cloud of components B can model fluctuations in the X or Y production rates.

caption.title: Definition of the class of systems modeling a gene and its passive reporter.
caption.p: Given a component Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} that is not affected by X or Y, we define A to be all the components in the network that affect Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}, along with all the components that affect the degradation rates of X and Y, along with the component Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} itself. We define B to be all the components that are not affected by X or i and that are not in the set A. The union of A and B make up the cloud of components zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} in Appendix 1—figure 21 that are not affected by X or Y. We show in this section that the proof of Equation 2 still holds when the production rates of X and Y differ by fluctuations that arise from the cloud of components B.

sec.p: Let Rx(x,y,zaff,A,B)\begin{document}$R_{x}(x,y,\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})$\end{document} and Ry(x,y,zaff,A,B)\begin{document}$ R_{y}(x,y,\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})$\end{document} be the production rates of X and Y, respectively. We can condition on the history of A, in which case the following differential equations follow similarly to Equation 5.5:(7.2)dx¯¯dt=R¯¯x(t)−x¯¯β¯¯(t)&dy¯¯dt=R¯¯y(t)−y¯¯β¯¯(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d \bar{\bar{x}} }{dt} = \bar{\bar{R}}_{x}(t) - \bar{\bar{x}}\bar{\bar{\beta}}(t) \quad \& \quad \frac{d \bar{\bar{y}}}{dt} = \bar{\bar{R}}_{y}(t) - \bar{\bar{y}}\bar{\bar{\beta}}(t), $$\end{document}

x¯¯(t)=E[xt|A[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{\bar{x}}(t) = E\left[x_{t}|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document} where , y¯¯(t)=E[yt|A[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{\bar{y}}(t) = E\left[y_{t}|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document}, and β¯¯(t)=E[β(A(t))|A[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{\bar{\beta}}(t) = E\left[\beta(\mathbf{A}(t))|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document}, and whereR¯¯x(t)=E[Rx(xt,yt,zaff,A(t),B(t))|A[−∞,t]],R¯¯y(t)=E[Ry(xt,yt,zaff,A(t),B(t))|A[−∞,t]].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} &\bar{\bar{R}}_{x}(t) = E\left[R_{x}(x_{t},y_{t},\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{A}(t),\mathbf{B}(t))|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right], \\ &\bar{\bar{R}}_{y}(t) = E\left[R_{y}(x_{t},y_{t},\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{A}(t),\mathbf{B}(t))|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]. \end{array}$$\end{document}

These are the average production rates conditioned on the history of the components A. Note that Equation 7.2 is identical to Equation 5.5 if the average conditional rates are proportional to one another:(7.3)R¯¯x(t)∝R¯¯y(t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{\bar{R}}_{x}(t) \propto \bar{\bar{R}}_{y}(t).$$\end{document}
As long as Equation 7.3 holds, the derivation that follows Equation 5.5 applies here and it follows that ηxzk=ηyzk\begin{document}$\eta_{xz_{k}}=\eta_{yz_{k}}$\end{document}.

As a result, Rx\begin{document}$R_{x}$\end{document} and Ry\begin{document}$R_{y}$\end{document} can differ by any fluctuations that come out of the components in B or those in zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} that average out when taking the average conditioned on the history of the components in A.

sec.title: Additive fluctuations
sec.p: The covariability relation of Equation 2 still holds if the production rates differ by some unspecified additive fluctuations that average out to zero. That is, if we have an unspecified additive noise term δ:(7.4)Rx(xt,yt,zaff(t),A(t),B(t))=Ry(xt,yt,zaff(t),A(t),B(t))+δ(xt,yt,zaff,A,B)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle R_{x}(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}(t), \mathbf{A}(t), \mathbf{B}(t)) = R_{y}(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}(t), \mathbf{A}(t), \mathbf{B}(t)) + \delta(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B})$$\end{document}

such that E[δ(xt,yt,zaff,A,B)|A[−∞,t]]=0\begin{document}$E\left[\delta(x_{t},y_{t},\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})| \mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]=0$\end{document}. This noise term δ\begin{document}$ \delta$\end{document} can depend in an arbitrary way on components in the system, as long as the fluctuations average out to zero when conditioned on the upstream history of A.

For example, we can consider the following birth-death process:(7.5)w→λw+1p→λpp+1x→w+K(p−δ⟨p⟩)x+1y→wy+1z→wz+1w→w/τw−1p→p/τpp−1x→x/τx−1y→y/τy−1z→z/τz−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{cc}w\xrightarrow{\lambda}w+1 \quad p\xrightarrow{\lambda_{p}}p+1 \quad x\xrightarrow{w + K(p - \delta \langle p \rangle) } x+1 \quad y\xrightarrow{w } y+1 \quad z\xrightarrow{w } z+1 \\ w\xrightarrow{w/\tau}w-1 \quad p\xrightarrow{ p/\tau_{p}}p-1 \quad x\xrightarrow{ x/\tau} x-1 \quad y\xrightarrow{ y/\tau} y-1 \quad z\xrightarrow{ z/\tau} z-1 \end{array}$$\end{document}

Here, X and Y have production rates given by the abundance of W, with X having an additional additive term K(p−δ⟨p⟩)\begin{document}$ K(p-\delta\langle p\rangle)$\end{document} which depends on the fluctuations in p\begin{document}$ p$\end{document} abundances. Both W and p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} fluctuate according to a Poisson process. Crucially, when δ=1\begin{document}$\delta=1$\end{document} the additive noise term will average to zero, in which case the invariant of Equation 2 must still be satisfied because X and Y do not affect Z, see Appendix 1—figure 23A. However, when δ=0\begin{document}$\delta=0$\end{document} the additive noise term does not average to zero, which can lead to a deviation of Equation 2 even when X and Y do not affect Z, see Appendix 1—figure 23B. This indicates that deviations from Equation 2 can occur when the X and Y production rates differ by certain types of fluctuations even when X and Y do not affect Z.

caption.title: An example system shows that the invariant holds when the rates differ by additive fluctuations that average to zero.
caption.p: (A) Simulations of the birth-death process of Equation 7.5 with δ=1\begin{document}$\delta=1$\end{document}, which ensures that the additive noise term averages to zero. Each dot corresponds to a single iteration of the Gillespie algorithm that was run until each reaction occurred at least 107 times. In each dot, the parameters are τ=1\begin{document}$\tau=1$\end{document}, τp=0.1\begin{document}$\tau_{p}=0.1$\end{document}, λp=5/τp\begin{document}$\lambda_{p}=5/\tau_{p}$\end{document}, λ=10\begin{document}$\lambda=10$\end{document}. The K parameter quantifies the strength of the additive noise and was varied from 0 to 40 in increments of 2, with each dot having a particular K value. As can be seen, the dots all lie on or very near the line given by Equation 2. Small deviations from the line are inevitable and are due to numerical errors brought on by finite sampling of the stochastic process. (B) Same as in A except now δ=0\begin{document}$\delta=0$\end{document}, which means the additive noise term does not average to zero. Here as the K parameter is increased and more noise is added to the X production rate, there is further deviation from Equation 2 even as X and Y do not affect Z.

sec.p: As an example, an additive noise term of this type can be the result of a linear cascade of an unspecified number of variables upstream of X and Y. That is, consider the following systemx1→R(zaff,zaffc)x1+1x2→λ2x1x2+1…xn→λnxn−1xn+1x1→β1(zaffc)x1−1x2→β2(zaffc)x2−1…xn→βn(zaffc)xn−1y1→α1R(zaff,zaffc)y1+1y2→α2λ2y1y2+1…yn→αnλnyn−1yn+1y1→β1(zaffc)y1−1y2→β2(zaffc)y2−1…yn→βn(zaffc)yn−1x→λxnx+1y→αλyny+1x→xβ(zaffc)x−1y→yβ(zaffc)y−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} x_{1} \xrightarrow{R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}x_{1}+1 \quad x_{2} \xrightarrow{\lambda_{2}x_{1}}x_{2}+1 \quad \dots \quad x_{n} \xrightarrow{\lambda_{n}x_{n-1}}x_{n}+1 \\ x_{1} \xrightarrow{\beta_{1}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}x_{1}-1 \quad x_{2} \xrightarrow{\beta_{2}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}x_{2}-1 \quad \dots \quad x_{n} \xrightarrow{\beta_{n}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}x_{n}-1 \\ \quad \\ y_{1} \xrightarrow{\alpha_{1}R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}y_{1}+1 \quad y_{2} \xrightarrow{\alpha_{2}\lambda_{2}y_{1}}y_{2}+1 \quad \dots \quad y_{n} \xrightarrow{\alpha_{n}\lambda_{n}y_{n-1}}y_{n}+1 \\ y_{1} \xrightarrow{\beta_{1}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}y_{1}-1 \quad y_{2} \xrightarrow{\beta_{2}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}y_{2}-1 \quad \dots \quad y_{n} \xrightarrow{\beta_{n}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}y_{n}-1 \\ \quad \\ x \xrightarrow{\lambda x_{n} }x+1\qquad \qquad y\xrightarrow{\alpha \lambda y_{n}}y+1 \qquad \qquad \\ x \xrightarrow{x\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}x-1\quad \qquad y\xrightarrow{y\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})}y-1 \quad \qquad \end{array}$$\end{document}

where the {λk}\begin{document}$\{\lambda_{k}\}$\end{document}, {αk}\begin{document}$\{\alpha_{k}\}$\end{document}, λ\begin{document}$ \lambda$\end{document}, and α\begin{document}$ \alpha$\end{document} parameters are unspecified constants. The result of this system is that the production rates of X and Y will differ by additive fluctuations, yet Theorem 1 still holds.

sec.title: Multiplicative noise that is independent of the production rates:
sec.p: The covariability relation of Equation 2 still holds if the production rates differ by some unspecified multiplicative fluctuations that are independent of the production rates:(7.6)Rx=nxR(xt,yt,zaff(t),A(t),B(t))andRy=nyR(xt,yt,zaff(t),A(t),B(t))\begin{document}$$\displaystyle R_{x} = n_{x}R(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}(t), \mathbf{A}(t), \mathbf{B}(t)) \quad \text{and} \quad R_{y} = n_{y}R(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}(t), \mathbf{A}(t), \mathbf{B}(t))$$\end{document}

where nx\begin{document}$ n_{x}$\end{document} and ny\begin{document}$ n_{y}$\end{document} are multiplicative random variables such thatE[nxR(xt,yt,zaff,A,B)|A[−∞,t]]=E[nx]⋅E[R(xt,yt,zaff,A,B)|A[−∞,t]]E[nyR(xt,yt,zaff,A,B)|A[−∞,t]]=E[ny]⋅E[R(xt,yt,zaff,A,B)|A[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}E\left[n_{x}R(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B})|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right] = E\left[n_{x}\right]\cdot E\left[R(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B})|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]\\ E\left[n_{y}R(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B})|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right] = E\left[n_{y}\right]\cdot E\left[R(x_{t}, y_{t}, \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}, \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B})|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]\end{array}$$\end{document}

and where E[nx|A[−∞,t]]=E[nx|A[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$E\left[n_{x}|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]=E\left[n_{x}|\mathbf{A}[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document}. These noise terms nx\begin{document}$ n_{x}$\end{document} and ny\begin{document}$ n_{y}$\end{document} can depend in an arbitrary way on components in the system, as long as they remain independent of the production rate R\begin{document}$ R$\end{document} when conditioned on the upstream history of A.

sec.title: 8. Bursty gene expression
sec.p: In Eukaryotes, a popular model of gene expression assumes that transcription occurs in bursts (Raj et al., 2006; Raj and van Oudenaarden, 2008; Bahar Halpern et al., 2015). The dynamics of such bursts are then described by the burst frequency and the burst size. Here we show that the invariant Equation 2 holds in the face of transcription bursting, as long as the burst frequency is identical for both geneX and the passive reporter geneY.

sec.title: Coordinated bursting
sec.p: Dual reporter genes with identical promoters have been engineered in mammalian cells (Raj et al., 2006), where it was observed that they underwent bursts in gene expression. Of note, the bursts between these dual reporters were highly correlated when the genes were placed at similar gene loci. On the other hand, the bursts were not correlated when placed at distant gene loci. We first consider the case where the dual reporters undergo perfectly coordinated bursting, which would model the former case.

In fact, the class of systems described in Section 4.1 encompasses such coordinated bursting transcription rates. The rate R\begin{document}$ R$\end{document} is left unspecified and can vary by switching stochastically between different states, which could model sudden bursts in the production of mRNA. This class of systems can include transcription rates with arbitrary bursting dynamics, frequencies, and burst sizes. The key assumption, however, is that a burst in geneX will occur at the same time as a burst in geneY.

sec.title: Un-coordinated bursting with constant burst sizes
sec.p: Bursts in mRNA abundances due to bursty transcription rates can be modeled by adding a burst size b\begin{document}$ b$\end{document} (a positive integer) to the class of systems:(8.1)x→R(zaff,zaffc)x+bxx→xβ(zaffc)x−1,y→αR(zaff,zaffc)y+byy→yβ(zaffc)y−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} &x \xrightarrow[]{R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} x+b_{x}\qquad \; x \xrightarrow[]{\; \; x\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}) \; \;} x-1 , \\ &y \xrightarrow[]{\alpha R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} y+b_{y}\qquad y \xrightarrow[]{\; \; y\beta(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}) \; \;} y-1 . \end{array} $$\end{document}

Here, R\begin{document}$ R$\end{document} corresponds to the burst frequency, while bx\begin{document}$b_{x}$\end{document} and by\begin{document}$b_{y}$\end{document} are the sizes of the bursts in the X and Y abundances, respectively. Of note, a burst in the X abundances can occur at a different time as a burst in Y abundances (and have a different size). The key assumption here is that the probability that a burst occurs at any given time in the Y abundance is proportional to the respective probability at the same given time for X.

The derivation described in Section 5 follows for this class of systems, with the exception that a factor of bx\begin{document}$b_{x}$\end{document} and by\begin{document}$b_{y}$\end{document} will go on front of the R¯(t)\begin{document}$\bar{R}(t)$\end{document} terms in Equation 5.5. Nevertheless, the normalized covariances are not affected by these burst sizes, and so the final result remains identical: the invariant of Equation 2 holds for this class of transcriptional bursting.

It has been hypothesized that chromatin remodeling is a cause of transcriptional bursting in Eukaryotes (Raj and van Oudenaarden, 2008). Under this model, transcription of a gene is free to occur when the surrounding chromatin is in an open state. When the chromatin is in a condensed state, however, transcription of the gene cannot occur. Under this hypothesis, the class of systems of Equation 8.1 could correspond to two genes located at different loci that each have the same probability at a given moment in time to suddenly be exposed due to stochastic chromatin remodeling.

sec.title: Un-coordinated bursting with distributed burst sizes
sec.p: In the previous section and in the class of systems described by Equation 8.1, the burst sizes bx\begin{document}$b_{x}$\end{document} and by\begin{document}$b_{y}$\end{document} are constant. Here, we show that the invariant of Equation 2 still holds when the burst sizes are distributed.
