Such distributed burst sizes can be modeled through a series of stochastic reactions that can occur for each possible burst size:(8.2)x→Rk(zaff,zaffc)x+kfor k=1,2,3,…\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x \xrightarrow[]{R_{k}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} x+k \qquad \text{for } k = 1, 2, 3, \dots $$\end{document}

Here, a burst of kX\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} molecules can be produced with probabilistic rate Rk\begin{document}$R_{k}$\end{document}. The production dynamics of the Y molecules are described by(8.3)y→αRk(zaff,zaffc)y+bykfor k=1,2,3,…\begin{document}$$\displaystyle y \xrightarrow[]{\alpha R_{k}(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\; \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c})} y+b_{y}k \qquad \text{for } k = 1, 2, 3, \dots $$\end{document}

Here, the burst frequencies for each possible burst size can be multiplied by an arbitrary factor α, and the burst sizes can also be multiplied by an arbitrary integer by\begin{document}$ b_{y}$\end{document}. Following the same derivation as described in Section 5, it follows that the invariant of Equation 2 holds for this class of systems that models un-coordinated bursting with distributed burst sizes. Note that since the individual rates Rk\begin{document}$R_{k}$\end{document} for each burst size are not specified, any distribution of burst sizes is included.

In this class of systems, a burst is modeled as occurring instantaneously. It remains to be shown that the invariant of Equation 2 holds in the face of slow bursts in transcription that are un-coordinated between the dual reporters.

sec.title: 9. Simulated example systems from Figure 1B
sec.p: To illustrate Equation 2 in Figure 1B of the main text, we simulated a number of four-component stochastic birth-death processes with the following general ratesx→rx+x+1y→ry+y+1zk→rz+zk+1w→rw+w+1x→rx−x−1y→ry−y−1zk→rz−zk−1w→rw−w−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} x\xrightarrow{r^{+}_{x}}x+1 \quad y\xrightarrow{r^{+}_{y}}y+1 \quad z_{k}\xrightarrow{ r^{+}_{z}} z_{k}+1 \quad w\xrightarrow{ r^{+}_{w}} w+1 \\ x\xrightarrow{r^{-}_{x}}x-1 \quad y\xrightarrow{r^{-}_{y}}y-1 \quad z_{k}\xrightarrow{ r^{-}_{z}} z_{k}-1 \quad w\xrightarrow{ r^{-}_{w}} w-1 \end{array}$$\end{document}
For cases in which X affects Z (circles in Figure 1B), we simulated the following systems.

list-item.p: rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_{x}^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_{y}^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λzx\begin{document}$r_{z}^{+} = \lambda_{z}x$\end{document} , rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{+} = \lambda_{w}$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_{x}^{-} = x/\tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_{y}^{-} = y/\tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_{z}^{-} = x/\tau_{z}$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{-} = w/\tau_{w}$\end{document}

rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_{x}^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_{y}^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λzw20.01+0.1x\begin{document}$r_{z}^{+} = \lambda_{z}\frac{w^{2}}{0.01+ 0.1x}$\end{document}, rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{+} = \lambda_{w}$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_{x}^{-} = x/\tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_{y}^{-} = y/\tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_{z}^{-} = x/\tau_{z}$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{-} = w/\tau_{w}$\end{document}

rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_{x}^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_{y}^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λzw20.01+0.001x\begin{document}$r_{z}^{+} = \lambda_{z}\frac{w^{2}}{0.01+ 0.001x}$\end{document}, rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{+} = \lambda_{w}$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_{x}^{-} = x/\tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_{y}^{-} = y/\tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_{z}^{-} = x/\tau_{z}$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{-} = w/\tau_{w}$\end{document}

rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_{x}^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_{y}^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λzx0.01+w\begin{document}$r_{z}^{+} = \lambda_{z}\frac{x}{0.01+ w}$\end{document}, rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{+} = \lambda_{w}$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_{x}^{-} = x/\tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_{y}^{-} = y/\tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_{z}^{-} = x/\tau_{z}$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{-} = w/\tau_{w}$\end{document}

rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_{x}^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_{y}^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λzw20.01+0.5x+w\begin{document}$r_{z}^{+} = \lambda_{z}\frac{w^{2}}{0.01+ 0.5x+w}$\end{document}, rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{+} = \lambda_{w}$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_{x}^{-} = x/\tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_{y}^{-} = y/\tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_{z}^{-} = x/\tau_{z}$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_{w}^{-} = w/\tau_{w}$\end{document}

sec.p: For cases in which X does not affect Z (squares in Figure 1B), we simulated the following systems.

list-item.p: rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_x^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_y^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λzw\begin{document}$r_z^{+} = \lambda_z w$\end{document}, rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_w^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_x^{-} = x / \tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_y^{-} = y / \tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_z^{-} = x / \tau_z$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_w^{-} = w / \tau_w$\end{document}.

rx+=λw\begin{document}$r_x^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, ry+=αλw\begin{document}$r_y^{+} = \alpha \lambda w$\end{document}, rz+=λz11+w\begin{document}$r_z^{+} = \lambda_z \frac{1}{1 + w}$\end{document}, rw+=λw\begin{document}$r_w^{+} = \lambda w$\end{document}, rx−=x/τ\begin{document}$r_x^{-} = x / \tau$\end{document}, ry−=y/τ\begin{document}$r_y^{-} = y / \tau$\end{document}, rz−=x/τz\begin{document}$r_z^{-} = x / \tau_z$\end{document}, rw−=w/τw\begin{document}$r_w^{-} = w / \tau_w$\end{document}.

sec.p: For each system, 1000 simulations were performed, each time randomly picking the following parameters α\begin{document}$ \alpha$\end{document}, τz\begin{document}$ \tau_{z}$\end{document}, τw\begin{document}$ \tau_{w}$\end{document}, λ\begin{document}$ \lambda$\end{document}, λz\begin{document}$ \lambda_{z}$\end{document}, and λw\begin{document}$ \lambda_{w}$\end{document} from the respective sets [0, 2], [0, 2], [0, 2], [0, 10], [0,10], and [0, 10], where [a, b] is defined as the set of all real numbers n\begin{document}$ n$\end{document} that satisfy a≤n≤b\begin{document}$a\leq n\leq b$\end{document}. The parameter τ was set to 1 throughout. Simulations were performed using the Gillespie algorithm (Gillespie, 1977) using C. Trajectories were simulated for 107 reaction events. Normalized covariances were computed by integrating over the trajectories to obtain time averages for first and second moments. This is equivalent to using the distribution given by calculating the fraction of the total system time spent in each sampled state. In the ergodic regime, this distribution converges to the stationary distribution of the ensemble.

No violations of Equation 2 were found, with plotted circles and squares corresponding to a representative sub-sample, with arbitrarily chosen sampling density, of our numerical simulations to indicate the accessible space

sec.title: 10. Example system with feedback from Appendix 1—figure 1
sec.p: For Appendix 1—figure 1, we simulated the following stochastic birth-death process(10.1)z→λzz+1x→R(x,z)x+1y→R(x,z)y+1withR(x,z)=λ(1+(xz+b)n)−1z→zβzz−1x→xβx−1y→yβy−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} z\xrightarrow{ \lambda_{z} }z+1 \quad \quad x\xrightarrow{ R(x,z) }x+1 \quad \quad y\xrightarrow{ R(x,z) }y+1 \quad \quad \text{with} \quad R(x,z) = \lambda \left(1 + \left(\frac{x}{z+b}\right)^{n}\right)^{-1} \\ z \xrightarrow{z\beta_{z}}z-1 \quad \quad x \xrightarrow{x \beta}x-1 \quad \quad y\xrightarrow{y \beta}y-1 \end{array} $$\end{document}

where λz=0.02\begin{document}$\lambda_{z}=0.02$\end{document}, βz=0.001\begin{document}$\beta_{z}=0.001$\end{document}, λ=10\begin{document}$ \lambda=10$\end{document}, b=0.01\begin{document}$ b=0.01$\end{document}, β=0.01\begin{document}$\beta=0.01$\end{document}, and n was varied to tune the feedback strength. In this system, Z affects both X and Y because the rate R depends on z. On the other hand, X is not affected by X and Y. The rate R also depends on the X numbers, leading to negative feedback in X but not in Y. This system was simulated using the Gillespie algorithm (Gillespie, 1977).

For Appendix 1—figure 1a we set n=20, and simulated the system for 100,000 reaction events. The initial conditions at t=0 were z=x=y=0. The time-trace shown in Appendix 1—figure 1a is a small segment of the total simulated time-trace, whereas the shown distributions are made by pooling the entire time-trace into distributions (the system is ergodic). The Z abundance was given a constant offset of 3 in Appendix 1—figure 1a for illustrative purposes to align the time-traces.

As a measure of feedback strength in this system, we use the absolute value of the logarithmic gain taken at the averagesFeedback strength=|(∂ln⁡(R(x,z))∂ln⁡(x)|⟨x⟩,⟨z⟩)|=n(⟨x⟩n(⟨z⟩+b)n+⟨x⟩n).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{Feedback strength} = \left| \left(\frac{\partial \ln \left(R(x,z)\right)}{\partial \ln \left(x\right)}\big|_{\langle x \rangle, \langle z \rangle} \right) \right | = n\left(\frac{\langle x \rangle ^{n}}{\left(\langle z \rangle + b\right)^{n} + \langle x \rangle ^{n}}\right).$$\end{document}

This quantifies how the rate R changes with x (Paulsson, 2004), and for this system is approximately equal to n. For Appendix 1—figure 1b we varied the feedback strength by simulating systems with different n from 0 to 9. Each simulation ran for 107 reaction events, and the Pearson correlation coefficients and the normalized covariances were computed from the distributions pooled from the sample paths as described above.

sec.title: 11. Details on the models simulated in Figure 2
sec.p: Here we provide details of the stochastic birth-death processes that were simulated to generate the normalized covariances plotted in Figure 2. The full model rates with selected parameters are described in Appendix 1—table 1. Additional details on the computation of the normalized covariances, as well as sampling error estimations, are discussed in the Materials and Methods of the main text. The algorithm used to simulate these systems is discussed in Section 14

In each of the process descriptions below, we first show the network topology, followed by the stochastic birth-death reactions. Note that some processes share the same topology but differ in the rate functions. Moreover, we denote [x]\begin{document}$\left[x\right]$\end{document} as the concentration of X, defined as x/V(t)\begin{document}$x/V(t)$\end{document}, where V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document} is the cell volume at time t (similarly for [y]\begin{document}$\left[y\right]$\end{document}, [z]\begin{document}$\left[z\right]$\end{document}, and [w]\begin{document}$\left[w\right]$\end{document}). Some of the rates depend directly on the cell volume V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document}. In these reactions, we write V(t)\begin{document}$ V(t)$\end{document} as V in the rate functions to shorten the notation, but it should be noted that when V is written in a rate function, it still corresponds to the cell volume at time t. The cell volume varies over time along with the molecular abundances, and three different volume dynamics are simulated as described in the Materials and methods section of the main text.

Note that in most of the systems below, we included a feedback mechanism. This is because feedback can make the dynamics of X and Y vastly different even though they are under the same control (see Appendix 1—figure 1). We thus added feedback in most of these systems to demonstrate that the invariant of Equation 2 holds even when X and Y have different dynamics.

caption.title: Process 1 — Negative feedback in X but not Y.
caption.p: Here the X and Y production rate depends linearly on the Z abundances, but is also suppressed by X abundances through negative feedback. The Z component is produced according to a Poisson process. This could model, for example, a gene regulated by an upstream transcription factor that also has an auto-repression mechanism. All components in this model are degraded with a first-order reaction with constant degradation constants.

caption.title: Process 2 — Asymmetric feedback.
caption.p: Though we state in the main text that Y is a passive reporter that does not affect other components in the network, in the proof of the invariant of Equation 2 we only assume that Y does not affect the Z component of interest. Therefore, as long as Y does not affect Z, the invariant of Equation 2 should hold even if X and Y are involved in a feedback mechanism that depends on different ways on the X and Y abundances. To test this, we simulated the process above. Here, the X and Y production rate is a hill function that increases with X and Z abundances, but has noise suppression in Y abundances. The δ parameter is a small number that is added to stop the rate from ever reaching zero when x=0 (otherwise the rate would stay at zero at the first moment that the X abundances hit zero). There is also a δ in the denominator to stop the denominator from ever becoming zero which would lead to numerical error.

caption.title: Process 3 — Negative feedback with a confounding variable.
caption.p: Next, we test the invariant on a process in which Z is correlated with X and Y through a confounding variable W. Here, X, Y, and Z are produced with rates that are proportional to the W abundances. However, the X and Y production rate is also suppressed by the X abundances through negative feedback. This could model, for example, a transcription factor that regulates X, Y, and Z, in which X is involved in an auto-repression mechanism.

caption.title: Process 4 — Negative feedback with concentration dependence 1.
caption.p: In the previous systems, the rates depend on the abundances of the components. However, reaction rates can depend on the concentration of components instead of the abundances, which will exhibit different dynamics in growing and dividing cells. In order to demonstrate that the invariant of Equation 2 holds when the reaction rates depend on concentrations, we simulated the above process. Here, the production rate of X and Y increases linearly with the Z concentration, but is suppressed by the X concentration. The Z production rate is a Poisson process, and all components undergo first-order degradation with constant degradation constant.

caption.title: Process 5 — Negative feedback with concentration dependence 2.
caption.p: Here we simulated another process with rates that depend on the component concentrations. However, here the rates scale with the cell volume V. This is to model a transcription rate that scales with the cell volume. In growing and dividing cells, this scaling in the transcription rate can allow for the mRNA concentration to be on average constant throughout the cell cycle, which has been observed in many genes. The δ parameter is added so that the denominator does not ever go to zero, which would cause numerical error.

caption.title: Process 6 — Shared time-varying upstream signal.
caption.p: Here we consider a process where the X, Y, and Z production rates are driven by a common upstream signal. This signal is a deterministic sine function. The rates scale with the cell volume V so that the rate of production of the concentrations, given by the abundance production rates divided by the cell volume, are themselves sine functions. This could model, for example, three genes that are co-regulated by an oscillating signal.

caption.title: Process 7 — Asymmetric feedback with confounding variable and concentration dependencies 1.
caption.p: This process is similar to process 2 in that the production rate of X and Y depends on both components in different ways. In particular, the shared production rate of X and Y is a hill function that increases with Y concentration but is suppressed by X concentrations. There is also a confounding variable W that regulates the dual reporters by acting as the hill coefficient in the shared production rate of X and Y. The Z production is also regulated by the W component, through a linear dependency on the W concentration.

caption.title: Process 8: Interaction mediated by a confounding variable.
caption.p: Here we have a process where the X and Y production rate is a hill function that depends non-linearly on the abundance of component W. In addition, the production rate of the W component is repressed by the Z concentration, which itself is repressed by the W concentration. Therefore, X and Y are correlated with Z because they are affected by Z (through W), but also because W affects X, Y, and Z.

caption.title: System 9 — Fluctuating degradation rates.
caption.p: In the previous process, the X and Y components underwent first-order degradation with constant degradation time. The invariant of Eq. (LABEL:EQ:_causality_constraint_(manuscript)) holds when the degradation constants fluctuate as long as they are not affected by X or Y (see Section 4.1). To demonstrate that the invariant holds with fluctuations in the degradation constants, we simulated the above process where the degradation constant is given by the Z abundance, where the production of Z follows a Poisson process. This could model, for example, stochastic fluctuations in the abundances of an enzyme that degrades the X and Y components.

caption.title: Process 10 — Oscillating degradation rates.
caption.p: This process is similar to the previous process, but here all the components are driven by a shared upstream oscillating signal. This could model, for example, a system where a degradation enzyme is regulated by an oscillating signal.

sec.title: 12. Derivation of Equation 2 in growing and dividing cells
A. Abundances
sec.p: The class of systems of Equation 2 does not consider the effect on the X and Y abundances caused by random partitioning of molecules at cell division. Here we show that Equation 2 still holds when cell division is added to the class of systems. In particular, the X and Y production and degradation reactions are governed by the same Equations 4.3; 4.4, with the addition that the shared unspecified production rate R can now depend on the cell volume V along with the other cellular components: R(zaff,zaffc,V)\begin{document}$R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c},V)$\end{document}.

Additionally, the cell volume divides at unspecified times {τk}\begin{document}$ \{\tau_{k}\}$\end{document} which can vary over the cell ensemble. At these moments, the volume is reduced by multiplicative factors that can lie between 0 and 1. That is, V→akV\begin{document}$ V\to a_{k}V$\end{document} at τk\begin{document}$ \tau_{k}$\end{document}, as we follow one of the daughter cells, where {ak}\begin{document}$ \{a_{k}\}$\end{document} is a set of factors, with each ak\begin{document}$ a_{k}$\end{document} satisfying 0<ak<1\begin{document}$ 0 \lt a_{k} \lt 1$\end{document}. As an example, in the case where cells divide perfectly symmetrically at every division, the factors would all be given by ak=1/2\begin{document}$a_{k}=1/2$\end{document}. In general, we allow for stochastic divisions in cell volume, that is we let the ak\begin{document}$ a_{k}$\end{document} factors be randomly distributed along with the division times through unspecified ensemble distributions.

At division times, the molecular content of the cell is divided between the two daughter cells. To allow for random partitioning of molecules at cell division, we let the X and Y abundances of a single lineage be reduced by unspecified distributions Ak(x)\begin{document}$\mathcal{A}_{k}(x)$\end{document} and Bk(y)\begin{document}$\mathcal{B}_{k}(y)$\end{document} that can vary over the divisions. We only specify that the averages satisfy ⟨Ak(x)⟩=akx\begin{document}$\langle\mathcal{A}_{k}(x)\rangle=a_{k}x$\end{document} and ⟨Bk(y)⟩=aky\begin{document}$\langle\mathcal{B}_{k}(y)\rangle=a_{k}y$\end{document}. That is, on average, the abundances are reduced in proportion to the cell division factors. As an example, the X and Y abundances could be divided according to a binomial distribution with probability ak\begin{document}$ a_{k}$\end{document} to remain in the tracked daughter cell.

In total, this amounts to adding the following ‘reaction’ to the class of systems(V,x,y)→At time τk(akV,Ak(x),Bk(y))for τ1,τ2,τ3…\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \big(\;V,\; x, \;y \;\big) \xrightarrow{\text{At time } \tau_{k}} \big(\;a_{k}V,\; \mathcal{A}_{k}(x),\; \mathcal{B}_{k}(y) \;\big) \quad \text{for } \tau_{1},\: \tau_{2}, \: \tau_{3} \dots$$\end{document}

To derive Equation 2, we define the two disjoint sets zaff\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}$\end{document} and zaffc\begin{document}$ \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} similarly to Section 4.1. In addition, we include the volume variable V\begin{document}$ V$\end{document} into the set of components not affected by X or Y. Similarly to Section. 5, we consider the average stochastic dual reporter dynamics conditioned on the history of their upstream influences: x¯(t)=E[xt|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{x}(t)=\mathrm{E}\big{[}x_{t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t],V[- \infty,t]\big{]}$\end{document} and y¯(t)=E[yt|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{y}(t)=\mathrm{E}\big{[}y_{t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t],V[- \infty,t]\big{]}$\end{document}. All cell lineages in this conditional probability space have the same volume history, so they all undergo divisions at the same times τ1,τ2,…\begin{document}$\tau_{1},\tau_{2},\dots$\end{document}, with the same division factors a1,a2,...\begin{document}$a_{1},a_{2},...$\end{document} (i.e. these are no longer random variables as they are conditioned on from the conditioning of the volume history). Between any two adjacent division times, τi\begin{document}$ \tau_{i}$\end{document} and τi+1\begin{document}$\tau_{i+1}$\end{document}, the time evolution is specified completely by the reactions in Equations 4.3; 4.4. That is, for τi<t<τi+1\begin{document}$\tau_{i} \lt t \lt \tau_{i+1}$\end{document}, the time evolution of the conditional averages is given by(12.1)dx¯dt=R¯(t)−x¯β(t)&dy¯dt=αR¯(t)−y¯β(t)whenτi<t<τi+1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\bar{x}}{dt} = \bar{R}(t) - \bar{x}\beta(t) \quad \& \quad \frac{d\bar{y}}{dt} = \alpha \bar{R}(t) - \bar{y}\beta(t) \quad \text{when} \quad \tau_{i} \lt t \lt \tau_{i+1},$$\end{document}

where R¯(t)=E[R(zaff,zaffc,V)|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$\bar{R}(t)=E[R(\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}},\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c},V)|\mathbf{z }_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t],V[-\infty,t]]$\end{document}. Division occurs at t=τi+1\begin{document}$t=\tau_{i+1}$\end{document}, at which point we have V(τi+1)→ai+1V(τi+1)\begin{document}$V(\tau_{i+1})\to a_{i+1}V(\tau_{i+1})$\end{document} and(12.2)x¯(τi+1)=E[xτi+1|zaffc[−∞,τi+1],V[−∞,τi+1]]→E[A(xτi+1|zaffc[−∞,τi+1],V[−∞,τi+1])]=ai+1x¯(τi+1),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{x}(\tau_{i+1}) &= \mathrm{E}\big[x_{\tau_{i+1}}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,\tau_{i+1}], V[-\infty,\tau_{i+1}] \big] \to \mathrm{E}\big[\mathcal{A}\left(x_{\tau_{i+1}}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,\tau_{i+1}], V[-\infty,\tau_{i+1}] \right) \big] \\ &= a_{i+1}\bar{x}(\tau_{i+1}),$$\end{document}

and similarly y¯(τi+1)→ai+1y¯(τi+1)\begin{document}$\bar{y}(\tau_{i+1})\to a_{i+1}\bar{y}(\tau_{i+1})$\end{document}. This gives us the boundary conditions for the above differential equation. Dividing the right equation in Equation 12.1 by α, we find that the two differential equations are identical in x¯\begin{document}$\bar{x}$\end{document} and y¯/α\begin{document}$ \bar{y}/\alpha$\end{document}, and they have the same boundary conditions. Once the transience of the system has vanished, we are left with x¯(t)=y¯(t)/α\begin{document}$\bar{x}(t)=\bar{y}(t)/\alpha$\end{document}. It then follows analogously to the proof of Theorem 1 that ηxzk=ηyzk\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz_{k}}=\eta_{yz_{k}}$\end{document} when Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} is any component not affected by X or Y.

sec.title: B. Concentrations
sec.p: We now show that Equation 2 holds in terms of the molecular concentrations of X and Y. In particular, we let xc:=x/V\begin{document}$x_{c}:=x/V$\end{document} and y:=y/V\begin{document}$y:=y/V$\end{document}, where x and y denote the abundances of X and Y, respectively. We condition on the history of the upstream influences and the volume:x¯c(t)=E[xtVt|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]=1V(t)E[xt|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]=x¯V(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{x}_{c}(t) = \mathrm{E}\Big[\frac{x_t}{V_{t}}\Big|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \Big] = \frac{1}{V(t)}\mathrm{E}\big[x_t|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \big] = \frac{\bar{x}}{V(t)} ,$$\end{document}

where V(t)\begin{document}$ V(t)$\end{document} can be pulled out from the expectation brackets since it is specified by the conditioning and becomes equivalent to a constant at time t. When τi<t<τi+1\begin{document}$\tau_{i} \lt t \lt \tau_{i+1}$\end{document}, Equation 12.1 governs the dynamics of x¯\begin{document}$\bar{x}$\end{document} and y¯\begin{document}$\bar{y}$\end{document}. We use the product rule to find(12.3)dx¯cdt=ddt(x¯V(t))=R¯c(t)−x¯cβ(t)−x¯cV′(t)V(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\bar{x}_{c}}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\bar{x}}{V(t)}\right) = \bar{R}_{c}(t) - \bar{x}_{c}\beta(t) - \bar{x}_{c}\frac{V'(t)}{V(t)} , $$\end{document}

where Rc:=R/V\begin{document}$R_{c}:=R/V$\end{document} is interpreted as the production rate of the concentration Xc\begin{document}$X_{c}$\end{document}. At division time τi+1\begin{document}$\tau_{i+1}$\end{document}, the cell volume is reduced V→ai+1V\begin{document}$V\to a_{i+1}V$\end{document} and so is x¯\begin{document}$\bar{x}$\end{document} (see Equation 12.2). We thus have x¯c→ai+1x¯ai+1V=x¯c\begin{document}$\bar{x}_{c}\to\frac{a_{i+1}\bar{x}}{a_{i+1}V}=\bar{x}_{c}$\end{document}, i.e., x¯c\begin{document}$\bar{x}_{c}$\end{document} is unchanged at the division times. As a result, x¯c(t)\begin{document}$\bar{x}_{c}(t)$\end{document} is continuous, meaning Equation 12.3 holds for all t. Note that Equation 12.3 holds for any volume dynamics between the division times, with the only requirement that it is a differential function between the division times.

We can then take the expectation of x¯c\begin{document}$\bar{x}_{c}$\end{document} over all possible histories of zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} and all possible histories of the volume dynamics V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document}(12.4)llE[x¯c(t)]histories=E[E[xt/V(t)|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]]histories=E[E[xt/Vt|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]]histories=⟨xt/V⟩=⟨xc⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {ll}E[\bar{x}_{c}(t)]_{\text{histories}} &= E\Big[ E \left[ x_{t}/V(t) | \mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \right] \Big]_{\text{histories}} \\ &= E\Big[E\left[x_{t}/V_{t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \right]\Big]_{\text{histories}} = \langle x_{t}/V \rangle = \langle x_{c} \rangle,$$\end{document}

which follows from the law of total expectation. We now consider any component Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} not affected by X or Y. It can be a molecular abundance, concentration, or another stochastic cellular variable like the growth rate of the cell. We then take the following expectation over all possible histories(12.5)llE[x¯c(t)zk(t)]histories=E[E[xc,t|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]⋅E[zk,t|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]]histories=E[E[xc,tzk,t|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]]histories=⟨xc,tzk,t⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {ll} E[\bar{x}_{c}(t)z_{k}(t)]_{\text{histories}} &= E\Big[ E\left[x_{c,t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \right] \cdot E\left[z_{k,t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \right] \Big]_{\text{histories}} \\ &= E\Big[E\left[x_{c,t}z_{k,t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], V[-\infty,t] \right]\Big]_{\text{histories}} = \langle x_{c,t}z_{k,t} \rangle , $$\end{document}

where the second step comes from the fact that conditioning on the history of zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} effectively conditions on the history of zk\begin{document}$z_{k}$\end{document} (so xc\begin{document}$x_{c}$\end{document} and zk\begin{document}$z_{k}$\end{document} are independent when conditioning on the zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} history), the last step follows from the law of total expectation, xc,t\begin{document}$ x_{c,t}$\end{document} is the concentration of X at time t, zk,t\begin{document}$z_{k,t}$\end{document} is the measured quantity of Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} at time t, and zk(t)=E[zk,t|zaffc[−∞,t],V[−∞,t]]\begin{document}$z_{k}(t)=E\left[z_{k,t}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t],V[-\infty,t]\right]$\end{document} which is fully determined through the conditioning of the history of zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} of which Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} is an element. From Equations 12.4; 12.5, it follows that(12.6)Cov(xc,t,zk,t)=Cov(x¯c(t),zk(t)).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{Cov}\left(x_{c,t},z_{k,t}\right) = \text{Cov}\left(\bar{x}_{c}(t),z_{k}(t) \right) .$$\end{document}

Similarly, we can derive the equivalent differential equation for the Y concentration(12.7)dy¯cdt=αR¯c(t)−y¯cβ(t)−y¯cV′(t)V(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\bar{y}_{c}}{dt} = \alpha \bar{R}_{c}(t) - \bar{y}_{c}\beta(t) - \bar{y}_{c}\frac{V'(t)}{V(t)} , $$\end{document}

which holds for all t. Dividing Equation 12.7 by α, we find that the differential equations governing x¯c(t)\begin{document}$\bar{x}_{c}(t)$\end{document} and y¯c(t)/α\begin{document}$\bar{y}_{c}(t)/\alpha$\end{document} are identical. As a result, after the initial transience has decayed, we have x¯c(t)=y¯c(t)/α\begin{document}$\bar{x}_{c}(t)=\bar{y}_{c}(t)/\alpha$\end{document}. We can thus derive the analogues of Equations 12.3; 12.4 for y¯/α\begin{document}$\bar{y}/\alpha$\end{document}. It then follows that(12.8)⟨xc⟩=⟨yc⟩/α&Cov(xc,zk)=Cov(yc,zk)/α.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{c} \rangle = \langle y_{c} \rangle/\alpha \quad \& \quad \text{Cov}(x_{c},z_{k}) = \text{Cov}(y_{c},z_{k})/\alpha.$$\end{document}

Dividing Cov(xc,zk)\begin{document}$\text{Cov}(x_{c},z_{k})$\end{document} by ⟨xc⟩⟨zk⟩\begin{document}$\langle x_{c}\rangle\langle z_{k}\rangle$\end{document}, and Cov(yc,zk)/α\begin{document}$\text{Cov}(y_{c},z_{k})/\alpha$\end{document} by ⟨yc⟩⟨zk⟩/α\begin{document}$\langle y_{c}\rangle\langle z_{k}\rangle/\alpha$\end{document}, we findηxczk=ηyczk.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta_{x_{c}z_{k}} = \eta_{y_{c}z_{k}}.$$\end{document}
If we then re-label the variables and let x\begin{document}$ x$\end{document} and y\begin{document}$ y$\end{document} denote concentrations of X and Z respectively, we obtain Equation 2.

sec.title: 13. Simulation algorithm for growing and dividing cells
sec.p: Many of the processes in Appendix 1—table 1 have time-dependent rates through the time-varying cell volume V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document}. As a result, we employ the Gillespie algorithm Gillespie, 1977 in combination with a ‘trick’ that allows us to simulate exact time trajectories of the abundances and concentrations with time-varying rates (Voliotis et al., 2016).

First, we simulate the division times and division factors for a single growing and dividing cell. There are three volume dynamics that we consider; see Materials and methods of the main text. In the first two, division times and division factors are constant. We set the constant division times to 1 and division factors to 1/2. The third is simulated with a simple Python script which produces an array of division times {τi}\begin{document}$\{\tau_{i}\}$\end{document} and division factors {ai}\begin{document}$\{a_{i}\}$\end{document} as described in the Materials and Methods of the main text.
The algorithm is then as follows:

list-item.p: The state of the system at time t0\begin{document}$ t_{0}$\end{document} is s=(x,y,z,w)\begin{document}$\mathbf{s}=(x,\;y,\;z,\;w)$\end{document}. The waiting time t\begin{document}$ t$\end{document} for the next reaction event to occur is chosen by picking a random number from an exponential distribution with cumulative distribution function F(t)=1−e−∫tt0+trT(s,t)dt\begin{document}$F(t)=1-e^{-\int_{t}^{t_{0}+t}r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)dt}$\end{document}, where rT(s,t)\begin{document}$r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)$\end{document} is the total rate of reaction events at time t\begin{document}$ t$\end{document}:rT|(s,t)=rx+(s,t)+rx−(s,t)+ry+(s,t)+ry−(s,t)+rz+(s,t)+rz−(s,t),rw+(s,t)+rw−(s,t)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle r_T |(\mathbf{s},t) = r_x^+(\mathbf{s},t) + r_x^-(\mathbf{s},t)+ r_y^+ (\mathbf{s},t) + r_y^-(\mathbf{s},t) + r_z^+(\mathbf{s},t) + r_z^-(\mathbf{s},t), r_w^+(\mathbf{s},t) + r_w^-(\mathbf{s},t)$$\end{document}

with the rates given in S Appendix 1—table 1 and the t\begin{document}$ t$\end{document} dependence comes through the time dependent functions V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document} and sin⁡(ωt)\begin{document}$\sin(\omega t)$\end{document} in the rates. Determining the waiting time from this distribution requires numerically integrating rT(s,t)\begin{document}$r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)$\end{document} which is computationally time-consuming while introducing numerical error. Instead, we use the following trick. We introduce a virtual component ϕ\begin{document}$ \phi$\end{document} that follows the following null rate(13.1)ϕ→rϕ(s,t)ϕ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \phi\xrightarrow{{r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s},t)}}\phi,$$\end{document}

where rϕ(s,t)\begin{document}$r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s},t)$\end{document} is a function that satisfies rϕ(s,t)+rT(s,t)=f(s)>0\begin{document}$r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s},t)+r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)=f(\mathbf{s}) \gt 0$\end{document}. That is, adding rϕ(s,t)\begin{document}$ r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s},t)$\end{document} to rT(s,t)\begin{document}$r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)$\end{document} eliminates the explicit time dependence and leads to a positive function f that only depends on the state s. For example, in process 6 from Appendix 1—table 1, we can take rϕ(s,t)=max{rT(s,t)}t−rT(s,t)\begin{document}$r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s},t)=\max\{r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)\}_{t}-r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)$\end{document}, wheremax{rT(s,t)}t=2AVmax+2BVmax+2CVmax+xβ+yβ+zβz,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \max\{r_{T}(\mathbf{s}, t)\}_{t} = 2AV_{max} + 2BV_{max} + 2CV_{max} + x\beta + y \beta + z \beta_{z},$$\end{document}

where Vmax\begin{document}$V_{max}$\end{document} is the max volume V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document} takes throughout the simulation. For instance, if V(t)\begin{document}$ V(t)$\end{document} exponentially grows from V0\begin{document}$ V_{0}$\end{document} to 2V0\begin{document}$ 2V_{0}$\end{document} and divides back to V0\begin{document}$ V_{0}$\end{document} with constant division times, then Vmax=2V0\begin{document}$V_{max}=2V_{0}$\end{document} (the first volume dynamics we consider). In another example, process 3, we could haverϕ(s,t)=(1+α)λz/Vmin+λz+xβ+yβ+zβz−rT(s,t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s}, t) = (1 + \alpha)\lambda z/ V_{min} + \lambda_{z} + x\beta + y \beta + z \beta_{z} - r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t).$$\end{document}

By introducing the null variable ϕ\begin{document}$ \phi$\end{document} into the system, the total reaction rate becomes r~T(s,t)=rϕ(s,t)+rT(s,t)=f(s)\begin{document}$\tilde{r}_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)=r_{\phi}(\mathbf{s},t)+r_{T}(\mathbf{s},t)=f(\mathbf{s})$\end{document}, a function that does not explicitly depend on time. As a result, since the abundances s do not change by definition of the waiting time in (t0,t0+t)\begin{document}$(t_{0},t_{0}+t)$\end{document}, the waiting time is picked from the following cumulative distribution function(13.2)F(t)=1−e−∫t0t0+tr~T(s,t)dt=1−e−f(s)t.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F(t) = 1 - e^{-\int_{t_{0}}^{t_{0} + t}\tilde{r}_{T}(\mathbf{s} , t)dt} = 1 - e^{-f(\mathbf{s}) t}.$$\end{document}

The waiting time t\begin{document}$ t$\end{document} for the next event to occur is thus generated through the cumulative distribution function given by Equation 13.2, which does not require numerical integration.

Check if a cell division {τi}\begin{document}$\{\tau_{i}\}$\end{document} occurred between time t0\begin{document}$ t_{0}$\end{document} and t0+t\begin{document}$t_{0}+t$\end{document}. If so, the system time is updated to when the division occurs: t0→τk\begin{document}$t_{0}\rightarrow\tau_{k}$\end{document} where τk\begin{document}$\tau_{k}$\end{document} the particular division time that occurred. We then update the cell volume that divides with the division factor ak\begin{document}$a_{k}$\end{document}: V(t0)→akV(t0)\begin{document}$V(t_{0})\rightarrow a_{k}V(t_{0})$\end{document}. The abundances are then reduced due to cell division and random partitioning

alternatives.tex-math: \begin{document}$(x, y, z, w) \longrightarrow (\mathrm{Bin}(x, a_k), \mathrm{Bin}(y, a_k), \mathrm{Bin}(z, a_k), \mathrm{Bin}(w, a_k)), $\end{document}

list-item.p: where Bin(x,ak)\begin{document}$ \text{Bin}(x,a_{k})$\end{document} is the binomial distribution on x\begin{document}$ x$\end{document} with probability ak\begin{document}$a_{k}$\end{document}. We then go back to step 1.

Else, if no division time occurred between t0\begin{document}$t_{0}$\end{document} and t0+t\begin{document}$t_{0}+t$\end{document}, then update the cell volume V→V(t0+t)\begin{document}$V\rightarrow V(t_{0}+t)$\end{document}. Then determine which of the reactions occurs at the time t0+t\begin{document}$t_{0}+t$\end{document}, where the i-th reaction occurs with probability rir~T\begin{document}$\frac{r_{i}}{\tilde{r}_{T}}$\end{document}. For instance, an X molecule produced with probability rx+(s,t0+t)/r~T(s)\begin{document}$r^{+}_{x}(\mathbf{s},t_{0}+t)/\tilde{r}_{T}(\mathbf{s})$\end{document}.

Update the system according to the reaction that was determined in the previous step. For instance, if the event turns out to be that an X molecule is produced, the system is updated as(x,y,z,w)⟶(x+1,y,z,w).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle (x,\;y,\;z,\;w)\longrightarrow(x+1,\;y,\;z,\;w).$$\end{document}
Note that if the null reaction in Equation 13.1 is picked, nothing occurs.
Update the time: t0→t0+t\begin{document}$t_{0}\rightarrow t_{0}+t$\end{document}. Go back to 1 and re-iterate.

sec.title: 14. Simulation of a 10-component system with a regulatory cascade
sec.p: To demonstrate the invariant of Equation 2 in a system with many components, we simulated the following birth-death process. The following reactions describe the dynamics of the components not affected by X:(14.1)z1→1/(1+z22)z1+1,z2→1/(1+z32)z2+1,z3→1/(1+z12)z3+1,z4→1/(1+z12)z4+1,z5→z3z5+1,z6→z5z6+1,z7→z1/(1+z1)z7+1,z7→z7/2z7−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} & z_{1}\xrightarrow{1/(1 + z_{2}^{2})}z_{1}+1, \quad z_{2}\xrightarrow{1/(1 + z_{3}^{2})}z_{2}+1, \quad z_{3}\xrightarrow{1/(1 + z_{1}^{2})}z_{3}+1, \quad z_{4}\xrightarrow{1/(1 + z_{1}^{2})}z_{4}+1, \quad \\ & z_{5}\xrightarrow{z_3}z_{5}+1, \quad z_{6}\xrightarrow{z_5}z_{6}+1, \quad z_{7}\xrightarrow{z_1/(1 + z_1)}z_{7}+1, \quad z_{7}\xrightarrow{z_7/2}z_{7}-1. \end{array}$$\end{document}

The reactions that govern the X dynamics, as well as the passive reporter Y, are given by(14.2)x→2z1/(1+x)x+1,y→z1/(1+x)y+1,x→xx−1,y→yy−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} &x\xrightarrow{2z_{1}/(1 + x)}x+1, \quad y\xrightarrow{z_{1}/(1 + x)}y+1, \\ &x\xrightarrow{x}x-1, \quad y\xrightarrow{y}y-1. \end{array}$$\end{document}

Here, the production rate of X and Y depends linearly on Z1\begin{document}$Z_{1}$\end{document}, but is repressed through a negative feedback loop by X. The components that are affected by X form a regulatory cascade with non-linear hill function rates. The reactions that describe the dynamics of the components affected by X are:(14.3)z8→x3/(1+(x/2)3)z8+1,z9→z83/(1+(z8/2)3)z9+1,z10→z93/(1+(z9/2)3)z10+1,z8→z8z8−1,z9→z9z9−1,z10→z10z10−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} z_{8}\xrightarrow{x^{3}/\left(1 + (x/2)^{3}\right)}z_{8}+1, \quad z_{9}\xrightarrow{z_{8}^{3}/\left(1 + (z_{8}/2)^{3}\right)}z_{9}+1, \quad z_{10}\xrightarrow{z_{9}^{3}/\left(1 + (z_{9}/2)^{3}\right)}z_{10}+1, \\ z_{8}\xrightarrow{z_{8}}z_{8}-1, \quad z_{9}\xrightarrow{z_{9}}z_{9}-1, \quad z_{10}\xrightarrow{z_{10}}z_{10}-1. \end{array}$$\end{document}

In addition, we simulate growing and dividing cells, where the cell volume V(t)\begin{document}$V(t)$\end{document} divides by a factor of 2 at each cell division, with a fixed division time of td=1\begin{document}$t_{d}=1$\end{document}. Between two subsequent divisions that occur at times τi\begin{document}$ \tau_{i}$\end{document} and τi+1\begin{document}$\tau_{i+1}$\end{document} respectively, the volume grows exponentially: V(t)=2(t−τi)\begin{document}$V(t)=2^{(t-\tau_{i})}$\end{document}. At each division, the abundances of each molecule from the reaction network above are reduced according to a binomial distribution with probability 0.5.

The reaction network topology for this system is shown in Appendix 1—figure 34. The normalized covariances computed from simulations of this network are plotted in Appendix 1—figure 34B. All components not affected by X satisfy the invariant of Equation 2, whereas the three components that are affected by X display a clear violation of the invariant.

caption.title: Equation 2 is satisfied in an example network made of 10 components.
caption.p: (A) The reaction network topology for the system given by Equations 14.1; 14.2; 14.3. Blue squares are components not affected by X. Red circles are affected by X. (B) Plotted are the normalized covariances between the concentrations of X, Y with those of the other components in the network. Components that are not affected by X (blue squares) satisfy the invariant of Equation 2. Components affected by X (red circles) violate the invariant. Note, the further down the cascade regulated by X, the closer the normalized covariances move towards the dashed line. This suggests that the distance from the dashed line is inversely proportional to the relative distances of components down regulatory cascades. Simulations were performed according to the algorithm described in Section 13. Normalized covariances were computed by integrating over the trajectories to obtain time averages for first and second moments, waiting for 10,000 cell divisions to occur before integrating to allow the system to reach stationarity. Each computed normalized covariance corresponds to the average of 40 independent simulations that ran for 106 cell divisions. Estimated 95% confidence intervals (which are too minuscule to see) for the normalized covariances correspond to two times the standard error of the mean over these 40 simulations. Using error propagation, in each of the components not affected by X, the ratio ηxzi/ηyzi\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz_{i}}/\eta_{yz_{i}}$\end{document} produced 95% confidence intervals that encompassed the predicted value of 1. See Materials and methods for additional simulation details.

sec.p: In Appendix 1—figure 34B we find that, of the components that are affected by X, the normalized covariances with Z8\begin{document}$Z_{8}$\end{document} lie furthest away from the dashed line given by Equation 2, whereas the normalized covariances with Z10\begin{document}$Z_{10}$\end{document} lie closest. This suggests that the “distance” down a regulatory cascade can scale inversely with the degree to which the normalized covariances violate Equation 2.

Note that the strength of an interaction is not the sole factor that affects the degree to which Equation 2 is violated. In particular, though the dual reporters X and Y are identically regulated, they will differ due to the probabilistic nature of the reactions governing their dynamics. These ‘intrinsic fluctuations’ are what we exploit to detect causal interactions: when X affects a component of interest Z, but Y does not, then the intrinsic fluctuations in X will propagate to Z, but those from Y will not, thus creating an asymmetry between the normalized covariances. Therefore, the size of these intrinsic fluctuations affects the difference between the normalized covariances when there is a causal interaction. As a result, the degree to which Equation 2 is violated cannot equate to an absolute measure for the distance down a regulatory cascade, because both the strength of the interaction and the size of the intrinsic fluctuations in X affect the degree of violation.

However, it might be possible to infer the relative distance down a cascade. That is, in a given network, the normalized covariances between X, Y, and two other components of interest Zi\begin{document}$Z_{i}$\end{document}, Zj\begin{document}$Z_{j}$\end{document} that are affected by X can be compared. If the asymmetry between ηxzi\begin{document}$\eta_{xz_{i}}$\end{document} and ηyzi\begin{document}$\eta_{yz_{i}}$\end{document} is larger than the asymmetry between ηxzj\begin{document}$\eta_{xz_{j}}$\end{document} and ηyzj\begin{document}$\eta_{yz_{j}}$\end{document}, then we might be able to conclude that X affects Zi\begin{document}$Z_{i}$\end{document} with a stronger interaction than the interaction from X to Zj\begin{document}$Z_{j}$\end{document}, because here the intrinsic fluctuations in X are the same in both cases.

Note that in the particular example in Appendix 1—figure 34A, the definition of “distance” down the regulatory cascade is clear. However, if there exists feedback from any of the components in the cascade back onto X and Y, then this definition is not well defined.

sec.title: 15. Fluctuations in plasmid copy numbers can reduce the degree of violation of Equation 2
sec.p: All 4 of the positive control synthetic circuits used in this study have the target geneZ placed on a plasmid. All genes placed on the same plasmid will be impacted by the shared fluctuations that originate from plasmid copy number fluctuations. If the plasmid fluctuations are large enough, they can reduce any differences between ηxz\begin{document}$ \eta_{xz}$\end{document} and ηyz\begin{document}$ \eta_{yz}$\end{document} that result from a causal interaction from X to Z. To demonstrate this, we simulated the following two birth-death processes. The following reactions describe the dynamics of an open-loop regulatory cascade:(15.1)w→pλw+1,x→pλ/(1+(w2K))x+1,y→pλ/(1+(wK)2)y+1,z→pλ/(1+(zK)2)z+1,w→w/τw−1,x→x/τx−1,y→y/τy−1,z→x/τz−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} &w\xrightarrow{p\lambda}w+1, \quad x\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{w^{2}}{K}\right) \right)}x+1, \quad y\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{w}{K}\right)^{2} \right)}y+1, \quad z\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{z}{K}\right)^{2} \right)}z+1, \\[5pt] &w\xrightarrow{w/\tau}w - 1, \quad x\xrightarrow{x/\tau}x - 1, \quad y\xrightarrow{y/\tau}y - 1, \quad z\xrightarrow{x/\tau}z - 1. \end{array}$$\end{document}

Here, W represses the production X and Y, while X represses the production of Z. The production rates are proportional to the plasmid copy number p\begin{document}$ p$\end{document} which can also fluctuate. The following reactions describe the dynamics of a closed-loop regulatory cascade:(15.2)w→pλ/(1+(zK)3)w+1,x→pλ/(1+(wK)3)x+1,y→pλ/(1+(wK)3)y+1,z→pλ/(1+(zK)3)z+1,w→w/τw−1,x→x/τx−1,y→y/τy−1,z→x/τz−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} &w\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{z}{K}\right)^{3} \right)}w+1, \quad x\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{w}{K}\right)^{3} \right)}x+1, \quad y\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{w}{K}\right)^{3} \right)}y+1, \quad z\xrightarrow{p\lambda/\left( 1 + \left(\frac{z}{K}\right)^{3} \right)}z+1, \\[5pt] &w\xrightarrow{w/\tau}w - 1, \quad x\xrightarrow{x/\tau}x - 1, \quad y\xrightarrow{y/\tau}y - 1, \quad z\xrightarrow{x/\tau}z - 1. \end{array} $$\end{document}

Here, W represses the production X and Y, X represses the production of Z, and Z represses the production of W. The production rates are proportional to the plasmid copy number p\begin{document}$ p$\end{document} which can also fluctuate. We simulate the above two systems in two cases. In the first case, there are no plasmid copy number fluctuations, setting p=1\begin{document}$ p=1$\end{document} at all times. This corresponds to the case where the genes are all located on the chromosome. In the second case, there are plasmid copy number fluctuations with dynamics modeled by the following birth-death process:(15.3)p→λpp+1,p→p/τpp−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p\xrightarrow{\lambda_{p}}p+1, \quad p\xrightarrow{p/\tau_{p}}p-1.$$\end{document}

We randomly sample parameters for these systems and find that in the majority of cases, there is a larger degree of violation of Equation 2 in the case without plasmid fluctuations, see Appendix 1—figure 35.

caption.title: Fluctuations in plasmid copy numbers reduce the degree of violation of Equation 2 in simulated test cases.
caption.p: (A) Results of the simulations of the open-loop cascade system given by Equation 15.1. For each randomly sampled set of parameters, the system was simulated without plasmid fluctuations (p=1\begin{document}$ p=1$\end{document} is constant) and with plasmid fluctuations (with dynamics given by Equation 15.3). The degree of violation of the invariant of Equation 2 was computed as the absolute value of the ratio of the normalized covariances |ηxz/ηyz|\begin{document}$ |\eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}|$\end{document}. As X in this system represses the Z production rate, there can be a deviation from |ηxz/ηyz|=1\begin{document}$|\eta_{xz}/\eta_{yz}|=1$\end{document}. We find that the degree of violation of the invariant tends to be bigger in the case without plasmid fluctuations. (B) Similar to A but for simulations of the closed-loop cascade system given by Equation 5.12. We find that the degree of violation of the invariant tends to be bigger in the case without plasmid fluctuations. For both the open-loop and closed-loop systems, 100 sets of parameters were chosen randomly, with τ=1\begin{document}$\tau=1$\end{document}, λ=50r1\begin{document}$\lambda=50r_{1}$\end{document} and K=10r2\begin{document}$K=10r_{2}$\end{document} where ri\begin{document}$r_{i}$\end{document} are uniformly distributed random numbers in (0,1). Plasmid copy number fluctuations were simulated with τp=5r3\begin{document}$\tau_{p}=5r_{3}$\end{document} and λp=5/τp\begin{document}$\lambda_{p}=5/\tau_{p}$\end{document} which sets the average copy number to 5. Each simulation was performed using the Gillespie algorithm and ran until each reaction occurred at least 105 times.

sec.title: 16. The invariant relation holds in the face of measurement noise
sec.p: Here we show that Equation 2 holds when different types of measurement noise models are added to the class of dual reporter systems given by Equations 4.3; 4.4.

sec.title: A. Multiplicative noise
sec.p: Let Mx\begin{document}$ M_{x}$\end{document} and My\begin{document}$M_{y}$\end{document} be identically distributed random variables, independent of x and y, that model a multiplicative noise factor for X and Y respectively. If xm\begin{document}$x_{m}$\end{document} and ym\begin{document}$y_{m}$\end{document} are the measured abundances of X and Y respectively, then we have(16.1)xm=Mxx&ym=Myy,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x_{m} = M_{x}x \quad \& \quad y_{m} = M_{y}y ,$$\end{document}

where x\begin{document}$ x$\end{document} and y\begin{document}$ y$\end{document} are the true abundances of X and Y respectively. Let Zk\begin{document}$ Z_{k}$\end{document} be a component not affected by X or Y. If there is measurement noise that affects the Zk\begin{document}$ Z_{k}$\end{document} measurement, then we let it be arbitrary and include it in the zk\begin{document}$ z_{k}$\end{document} variable. We only assume that any dependence of Mx\begin{document}$ M_{x}$\end{document} and My\begin{document}$ M_{y}$\end{document} on zk\begin{document}$ z_{k}$\end{document} that occurs as a result of measurement noise is the same, that is E[Mx|zk]=E[My|zk]\begin{document}$ E[M_{x}|z_{k}]=E[M_{y}|z_{k}]$\end{document}. We use the law of total expectation as follows⟨Mxxzk⟩=E[E[Mxxzk|zaffc[−∞,t],Mx=m]]=E[mxzk(t)E[x|zaffc[−∞,t]]]=E[mzk(t)x¯(t)],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle M_{x}xz_{k} \rangle = E\Big[E \big[M_{x}xz_{k}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t], M_{x} = m \big]\Big] = E\Big[m_{x}z_{k}(t)E \big [x|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\big]\Big] = E\Big[mz_{k}(t)\bar{x}(t) \Big],$$\end{document}

where zk(t)\begin{document}$ z_{k}(t)$\end{document} is the determined zk\begin{document}$ z_{k}$\end{document} trajectory resulting from conditioning on the history of zkc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{k}^{c}$\end{document}, in the first step we condition on the history of the components not affected by X or Y along with the value of Mx\begin{document}$M_{x}$\end{document}, and where the expectation on the right is taken over all the possible histories of zaffc\begin{document}$\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}$\end{document} and all the possible values of Mx\begin{document}$M_{x}$\end{document}. Similarly, we have ⟨Myyzk⟩=E[mzk(t)y¯(t)]\begin{document}$\langle M_{y}yz_{k}\rangle=E[mz_{k}(t)\bar{y}(t)]$\end{document}. According to the paragraph above Equation 5.16, we have x¯(t)=y¯(t)/α\begin{document}$\bar{x}(t)=\bar{y}(t)/\alpha$\end{document}, therefor since Mx\begin{document}$M_{x}$\end{document} and My\begin{document}$M_{y}$\end{document} are identically distributed, we have⟨Mxxzk⟩=⟨Myyzk⟩/α.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle M_{x}xz_{k} \rangle = \langle M_{y}yz_{k} \rangle/\alpha.$$\end{document}
Similarly, we can derive⟨Mxx⟩=⟨Myy⟩/α.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle M_{x}x \rangle = \langle M_{y}y \rangle/\alpha.$$\end{document}
It follows from the above two equations and Equation 16.1 that ηxmzk=ηymzk\begin{document}$\eta_{x_{m}z_{k}}=\eta_{y_{m}z_{k}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: B. Additive noise
sec.p: Let Ax\begin{document}$A_{x}$\end{document} and Ay\begin{document}$A_{y}$\end{document} be random variables, with ⟨Ax⟩=⟨Ay⟩=0\begin{document}$\langle A_{x}\rangle=\langle A_{y}\rangle=0$\end{document}, that model an additive noise term for X and Y respectively. If xm\begin{document}$ x_{m}$\end{document} and ym\begin{document}$ y_{m}$\end{document} are the measured abundances of X and Y respectively, then we have(16.2)xm=x+Ax&ym=y+Ay,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x_{m} = x + A_{x} \quad \& \quad y_{m} = y + A_{y} ,$$\end{document}

where x and y are the true abundances of X and Y respectively. It follows that⟨xm⟩=⟨x⟩&⟨ym⟩=⟨y⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{m} \rangle = \langle x \rangle \quad \& \quad \langle y_{m} \rangle = \langle y \rangle.$$\end{document}

Let Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} be another cellular component. We assume that the additive noise terms in X and Y are statistically independent of zk\begin{document}$z_{k}$\end{document}. We thus haveCov(xm,zk)=Cov(x,zk)&Cov(ym,zk)=Cov(y,zk).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{Cov}(x_m, z_{k}) = \text{Cov}(x, z_{k}) \quad \& \quad \text{Cov}(y_{m}, z_{k}) = \text{Cov}(y, z_k).$$\end{document}

It follows that ηxmzk\begin{document}$\eta_{x_{m}z_{k}}$\end{document} = ηxzk\begin{document}$\eta_{xz_{k}}$\end{document} and ηymzk\begin{document}$\eta_{y_{m}z_{k}}$\end{document} = ηyzk\begin{document}$\eta_{yz_{k}}$\end{document}. If Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} is a component not affected by X or Y, then the invariant relation of Equation 2 must hold, and so ηxmzk=ηymzk\begin{document}$\eta_{x_{m}z_{k}}=\eta_{y_{m}z_{k}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: C. Binomial readout and undercounting noise
sec.p: Here we show how stochastic undercounting affects the invariant relation of Equation 2. This is motivated by the fact that common experimental methods can lead to a systematic undercounting of the mRNA levels and protein levels. For example, in fluorescence in situ hybridization, fluorescent probes only bind to mRNA molecules with a fixed probability. We would thus like to know how the invariant relation of Equation 2 changes when the reporter abundances X and Y are detected with fixed probabilities px\begin{document}$p_{x}$\end{document} and py\begin{document}$p_{y}$\end{document}, respectively. We let xm\begin{document}$ x_{m}$\end{document} and ym\begin{document}$ y_{m}$\end{document} correspond to the measured X and Y abundances, respectively. They are defined asxm=B(x,px)&ym=B(y,py),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x_{m} = B(x, p_{x}) \quad \& \quad y_{m} = B(y, p_{y}),$$\end{document}

where B(n,p)\begin{document}$B(n,p)$\end{document} is a binomial distribution with n trials with probability p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}. That is, when each molecule is detected with a fixed probability, the resulting measurement is a binomial readout of the true abundance. Taking the expectation, we have⟨xm⟩=E[B(x,px)]=E[E[B(x,px|x)]]=E[pxx]=px⟨x⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{m} \rangle = E[B(x,p_{x})] = E\big[E[B(x,p_{x}|x)]\big] = E[p_{x}x] = p_{x}\langle x \rangle.$$\end{document}

Now calculating the covariance with cellular component Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}, we have⟨xmz⟩=E[B(x,px)zk]=E[E[B(x,px)zk|x,zk]]=E[zkE[B(x,px)|x]]=E[pxxzk]=px⟨xz⟩\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle x_{m} z \rangle = E[B(x,p_{x})z_{k}] = E\Big[E\big[B(x,p_{x})z_{k}|x,z_{k}\big]\Big] = E\Big[z_{k}E[B(x,p_{x})|x]\Big] = E[p_{x}xz_{k}] = p_{x}\langle xz \rangle$$\end{document}⇒Cov(xm,zk)=⟨xmzk⟩−⟨xm⟩⟨zk⟩=pxCov(x,zk).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Rightarrow \text{Cov}(x_{m},z_{k}) = \langle x_{m}z_{k} \rangle - \langle x_{m} \rangle \langle z_{k} \rangle = p_{x}\text{Cov}(x,z_{k}).$$\end{document}
As a result, we haveηxmz=ηxz&ηymz=ηyz,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta_{x_{m}z} = \eta_{xz} \quad \& \quad \eta_{y_{m}z} = \eta_{yz},$$\end{document}

where the second equation follows by symmetry. Therefore, the normalized covariances are unaffected by the molecule detection probabilities. The invariant relation of Equation 2 thus holds in the face of systematic undercounting of molecules, allowing for arbitrary (and different) detection probabilities for X and Y.

sec.title: D. Poisson-Gaussian noise model
sec.p: Here we consider the case where measurement noise is introduced in fluorescent microscopy images. Fluorescent imaging noise is often modeled by the Poisson-Gaussian noise model which we consider here (Yang, 2015). If x~m\begin{document}$\tilde{x}_{m}$\end{document} and y~m\begin{document}$\tilde{y}_{m}$\end{document} are the measured intensities of the X and Y protein fluorescence, then we havex~m=1χP(χx~)+N(0,b),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde{x}_{m} = \frac{1}{\chi}\mathcal{P}(\chi \tilde{x}) + \mathcal{N}(0,b),$$\end{document}

where χ≥0\begin{document}$\chi\geq 0$\end{document} and b≥0\begin{document}$ b\geq 0$\end{document} are arbitrary constants, P\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}$\end{document} is the Poisson distribution, N\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}$\end{document} is the normal (Gaussian) distribution, and x~\begin{document}$ \tilde{x}$\end{document} is the original fluorescent signal which is proportional to the abundance x. Taking the expectation, we have(16.3)ll⟨x~m⟩=E[1χP(χx~)]+E[N(0,b)]=1χE[E[P(χx~)|x~]]+0=1χE[χx~]=⟨x~⟩=fx⟨x⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {ll} \langle \tilde{x}_{m} \rangle &= E\left[\frac{1}{\chi}\mathcal{P}(\chi \tilde{x})\right] + E\left[\mathcal{N}(0,b)\right] \\ &= \frac{1}{\chi} E\left[E[\mathcal{P}(\chi \tilde{x})|\tilde{x}]\right] + 0 \\ &= \frac{1}{\chi}E\left[\chi \tilde{x} \right] = \langle \tilde{x} \rangle = f_{x}\langle x \rangle, $$\end{document}

where fx\begin{document}$f_{x}$\end{document} is an unknown proportionality constant between the x~\begin{document}$ \tilde{x}$\end{document} signal and the protein abundance. That is, the expectation of the measured signal is the same as the expectation of the original signal. We now consider cellular component Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document}, which can correspond to the signal of another fluorescent protein in the cell and can have arbitrary measurement noise. Assuming that the measurement noise in Zk\begin{document}$Z_{k}$\end{document} is independent of the measurement noise in X and Y, which could be the case if three different images are taken in three different imaging channels, we take the covariance⟨x~mzk⟩=E[1χzkP(χx)]+E[zN(0,b)zk]=1χE[E[zkP(χx~)|x~,zk]]+E[E[zkN(0,b)|x~,zk]]=1χE[χx~zk]+0=⟨x~zk⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle \tilde{x}_{m} z_{k} \rangle &=E\left[\frac{1}{\chi}z_{k}\mathcal{P}(\chi x) \right] + E\left[z \mathcal{N}(0,b)z_{k}\right] \\ &= \frac{1}{\chi}E\left[E\left[z_{k}\mathcal{P}(\chi \tilde{x})|\tilde{x},z_{k}\right]\right] + E\left[E\left[z_{k}\mathcal{N}(0,b)|\tilde{x},z_{k}\right]\right] \\ &= \frac{1}{\chi}E\left[\chi \tilde{x}z_{k} \right] + 0 = \langle \tilde{x}z_{k} \rangle.$$\end{document}
Therefore(16.4)Cov(x~m,zk)=Cov(x~,zk)=fxCov(x,zk),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{Cov}(\tilde{x}_{m},z_{k}) = \text{Cov}(\tilde{x},z_{k}) = f_{x}\text{Cov}(x,z_{k}), $$\end{document}

where fx\begin{document}$f_{x}$\end{document} is an unknown proportionality constant between the x~\begin{document}$\tilde{x}$\end{document} signal and the protein abundance. Putting Equations 16.3; 16.4 together, we haveηx~mzk=ηxzk&ηy~mzk=ηyzk,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta_{\tilde{x}_{m}z_k} = \eta_{xz_k} \quad \& \quad \eta_{\tilde{y}_{m}z_k} = \eta_{yz_k},$$\end{document}
where the second equation follows by symmetry. The normalized covariances are thus not affected by the Poisson-Gaussian noise, and the invariant equation of Equation 2 can still be exploited.

sec.title: E. Segmentation noise
sec.p: Let x~m\begin{document}$\tilde{x}_{m}$\end{document} be the signal of the fluorescent X proteins that we measure. The image is made up of pixels which we index with p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, where the p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}-th pixel has intensity Ip\begin{document}$I_{p}$\end{document}. Each cell is segmented and has cell area A\begin{document}$ A$\end{document} and segmentation area S. The measured signal is thusx~m=∑p∈Sp∈AIp+∑p∈Sp∉AIp.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde{x}_{m} = \sum_{\substack{p \in S p \in A}}I_{p} + \sum_{\substack{p \in S p \notin A}}I_{p}. $$\end{document}

The second term corresponds to additive noise from whenever segmentation fits an area larger than the cell area. This corresponds to fluctuations in the image background. Assuming that the background can be removed and that these fluctuations are negligible compared to the fluorescent protein signal, we can set this term to zero. Moreover, assuming that the fluorescent proteins X are evenly distributed in the cell, then the third term on the right is just the fraction of the total signal that is in the segmentation area∑p∈Ap∈SIp=fxxθ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{\substack{p \in A p \in S}}I_{p} = f_{x}x\theta, $$\end{document}

where θ=S/A\begin{document}$\theta = S/A$\end{document} when S<A\begin{document}$S \lt A$\end{document} and θ=1\begin{document}$\theta = 1$\end{document} when S≥A\begin{document}$S \geq A$\end{document}, and fx\begin{document}$f_{x}$\end{document} is an unknown proportionality constant between the fluorescence and the abundance. We thus havex~m=fxθx,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde{x}_{m} = f_{x}\theta x , $$\end{document}

We now let θ\begin{document}$\theta$\end{document} be a stochastic variable that we include in the cloud of variables not affected by X, that is, the segmentation noise is not affected by x\begin{document}$x$\end{document} through an unspecified Markov chain. In that case, when we condition on the history of upstream variables in X, we can still write down Equation 5.5, and we still havex¯(t)=y¯(t)/α.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{x}(t) = \bar{y}(t)/\alpha. $$\end{document}

However, now we are also conditioning on the histories of θ\begin{document}$\theta$\end{document}, which means thatllfxθ(t)x¯(t)=fyθ(t)y¯(t)/(αfy/fx)⇒E[x~m|zaffc[−∞,t]]=E[y~m|zaffc[−∞,t]]/(αfy/fx)⇒E[E[x~m|zaffc[−∞,t]]]=E[E[y~m|zaffc[−∞,t]]]/(αfy/fx)⇒⟨x~m⟩=⟨y~m⟩/(αfy/fx).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {ll} f_{x}\theta(t)\bar{x}(t) =& \,f_{y}\theta(t)\bar{y}(t)/(\alpha f_{y}/f_{x}) \\ &\Rightarrow E\Big[\tilde{x}_{m}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\Big] = E\Big[\tilde{y}_{m}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\Big]/(\alpha f_{y}/f_{x}) \\ &\Rightarrow E\Big[E \big[\tilde{x}_{m}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\big]\Big] = E\Big[E\big[\tilde{y}_{m}|\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t]\big]\Big]/(\alpha f_{y}/f_{x}) \\ &\Rightarrow \langle \tilde{x}_{m} \rangle = \langle \tilde{y}_{m} \rangle /(\alpha f_{y}/f_{x}). $$\end{document}

Moreover, we have⟨x~mzk⟩=E[E[fxθxzk|zaffc[−∞,t]]]=fxE[θ(t)x¯(t)zk(t)]=⟨y~mzk⟩/(αfy/fx).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle \tilde{x}_{m}z_{k}\rangle = E\Big[E \big[f_{x} \theta x z_{k} |\mathbf{z}_{\text{aff}}^{c}[-\infty,t] \big] \Big] = f_{x} E\Big[\theta(t) \bar{x}(t) z_{k}(t) \Big] = \langle \tilde{y}_{m}z_{k} \rangle /(\alpha f_{y}/f_{x}). $$\end{document}
We thus have ηx~mzk=ηy~mzk\begin{document}$ \eta_{\tilde{x}_{m}z_{k}} = \eta_{\tilde{y}_{m}z_{k}}$\end{document}, and Equation 2 holds in the face of the segmentation noise modeled here.

sec.title: 17. Estimating confidence intervals
sec.p: The corrections from the preceding sections rely on the distribution of measurements. As a result, sampling error affects the corrections and their accuracy, along with the final estimators of the normalized covariances. Here, we show two methods we employed to estimate the confidence intervals for the normalized covariances, taking into account sampling error and its effect on the corrections discussed in the preceding sections. The computed normalized covariances and their confidence intervals for both methods are shown in Appendix 1—figure 16. The two methods give similar results (Figure 3D,E, Appendix 1—figure 6).

sec.title: A. Sampling with replacement (bootstrapping)
sec.p: The goal is to estimate the error bars for a normalized covariance measurement of a strain of cells in a mother machine experiment. Here we use bootstrapping, where the data corrections and the normalized covariances are computed over many samples of the data, allowing for replacement in sampling. If the experiment produces N fluorescence time-traces of cells with plasmid and M fluorescence time-traces of cells that lost the plasmid, the following pipeline computes the normalized covariance between the CFP and RFP proteins (the YFP and RFP case follows anagolously), see Appendix 1—figure 16A.
1. Take a random sample of size N of the cells with plasmid, allowing for replacement. Take another random sample of size M of the cells that lost the plasmid, allowing for replacement.

2. Use the sample of size N to compute the temporal drift curves of the CFP and RFP channels, and drift correct the data from both samples according to the procedure outlined in the temporal drift section above.

3. Compute the uneven illumination correction curves of the CFP and YFP channels, using the sample of size N, as outlined in the uneven illumination section above. Correct the data from both samples with the uneven illumination correction curves.

4. From the sample of size M (lost plasmid), pool data into a single distribution and compute the average CFP fluorescence. This corresponds to the autofluorescence and media fluorescence of the CFP channel.
5. Remove the autofluorescence and media fluorescence (obtained in the previous step) from all the CFP measurements from the sample of size N.
6. From the sample of size N, pool data into a single distribution and compute the normalized covariance between CFP and RFP of the sample ηsample\begin{document}$\eta^{sample}$\end{document}.
7. Go back to step 1 and repeat 100 times, saving each ηsample\begin{document}$ \eta_{sample}$\end{document}

8. When 100 normalized covariances ηsample\begin{document}$\eta_{sample}$\end{document} have been computed, take the average as the final η\begin{document}$\eta$\end{document} estimate, with confidence intervals given by 2 times the standard deviation of the 100 normalized covariances ηsample\begin{document}$\eta_{sample}$\end{document}.

sec.title: B. Sampling without replacement (splitting data)
sec.p: The goal is to estimate the error bars for a normalized covariance measurement of a strain of cells in a mother machine experiment. Here we divide the data from an experiment into Nsamples\begin{document}$N_{samples}$\end{document} disjoint sets. The data corrections and the normalized covariances are computed in each set. If the experiment produces N fluorescence time-traces of cells with plasmid and M fluorescence time-traces of cells that lost the plasmid, the following pipeline computes the normalized covariance between the CFP and RFP proteins (the YFP and RFP case follows anagolously), see Appendix 1—figure 16B.

1. Randomly divide the N cell traces into Nsamples=min(M,10)\begin{document}$N_{samples} = \text{min}(M,10)$\end{document} disjoint samples (each cell is in one and only one sample). Also randomly split the M cell traces with lost plasmid into Nsamples\begin{document}$N_{samples}$\end{document} disjoint sets. This ensures that each disjoint set has at least 1 cell that lost the plasmid to estimate the autofluorescence, but we cap the number of sets to 10 to allow for enough cells in each set. Most strains had more than 10 cells that lost the plasmid in a single mother machine experiment (the lowest was 7).

2. Take a sample of cells with plasmid and a sample of cells that lost plasmid. Compute the temporal drift curves of the CFP and RFP channels using the former sample, and drift correct the data from both samples according to the procedure outlined in the temporal drift section above.

3. Compute the uneven illumination correction curves of the CFP and YFP channels, using the sample of cells with plasmid, as outlined in the uneven illumination section above. Correct the data from both samples with the uneven illumination correction curves.

4. From the sample of size M (lost plasmid), pool data into a single distribution and compute the average CFP fluorescence. This corresponds to the autofluorescence and media fluorescence of the CFP channel.
5. Remove the autofluorescence and media fluorescence (obtained in the previous step) from all the CFP measurements from the sample of cells with plasmid.

6. From the sample of cells with plasmid, pool data into a single distribution and compute the normalized covariance between CFP and RFP of the sample ηsample\begin{document}$\eta^{sample}$\end{document}.
7. Go back to step 2 and repeat until ηsample\begin{document}$\eta^{sample}$\end{document} has been computed for each of the ηsample\begin{document}$\eta^{sample}$\end{document} samples.

8. When the Nsamples\begin{document}$N_{samples}$\end{document} normalized covariances ηsample\begin{document}$\eta_{sample}$\end{document} have been computed, take the average as the final η\begin{document}$\eta$\end{document} estimate, with confidence intervals given by 2 times the standard error of mean. Note that the denominator of the standard error is given by Nsamples−1\begin{document}$\sqrt{N_{samples} - 1}$\end{document} because a degree of freedom is used to compute the average.

body.p: By taking advantage of noise in gene expression, this important study introduces a new approach for detecting directed causal interactions between two genes without perturbing either. The main theoretical result is supported by a proof. Preliminary simulations and experiments on small circuits are solid, but further investigations are needed to demonstrate the broad applicability and scalability of the method.
Summary:

This paper describes a new approach to detecting directed causal interactions between two genes without directly perturbing either gene. To check whether gene X influences gene Z, a reporter gene (Y) is engineered into the cell in such a way that (1) Y is under the same transcriptional control as X, and (2) Y does not influence Z. Then, under the null hypothesis that X does not affect Z, the authors derive an equation that describes the relationship between the covariance of X and Z and the covariance of Y and Z. Violation of this relationship can then be used to detect causality.

The authors benchmark their approach experimentally in several synthetic circuits. In 4 positive control circuits, X is a TetR-YFP fusion protein that represses Z, which is an RFP reporter. The proposed approach detected the repression interaction in 2 of the 4 positive control circuits. The authors constructed 16 negative control circuit designs in which X was again TetR-YFP, but where Z was either a constitutively expressed reporter, or simply the cellular growth rate. The proposed method detected a causal effect in two of the 16 negative controls, which the authors argue is perhaps not a false positive, but due to an unexpected causal effect. Overall, the data support the potential value of the proposed approach.
Strengths:

The idea of a "no-causality control" in the context of detected directed gene interactions is a valuable conceptual advance that could potentially see play in a variety of settings where perturbation-based causality detection experiments are made difficult by practical considerations.

By proving their mathematical result in the context of a continuous-time Markov chain, the authors use a more realistic model of the cell than, for instance, a set of deterministic ordinary differential equations.
The authors have improved the clarity and completeness of their proof compared to a previous version of the manuscript.
Limitations:

The authors themselves clearly outline the primary limitations of the study: The experimental benchmark is a proof of principle, and limited to synthetic circuits involving a handful of genes expressed on plasmids in E. coli. As acknowledged in the Discussion, negative controls were chosen based on the absence of known interactions, rather than perturbation experiments. Further work is needed to establish that this technique applies to other organisms and to biological networks involving a wider variety of genes and cellular functions. It seems to me that this paper's objective is not to delineate the technique's practical domain of validity, but rather to motivate this future work, and I think it succeeds in that.
Might your new "Proposed additional tests" subsection be better housed under Discussion rather than Results?

I may have missed this, but it doesn't look like you ran simulation benchmarks of your bootstrap-based test for checking whether the normalized covariances are equal. It would be useful to see in simulations how the true and false positive rates of that test vary with the usual suspects like sample size and noise strengths.

It looks like you estimated the uncertainty for eta_xz and eta_yz separately. Can you get the joint distribution? If you can do that, my intuition is you might be able to improve the power of the test (and maybe detect positive control #3?). For instance, if you can get your bootstraps for eta_xz and eta_yz together, could you just use a paired t-test to check for equality of means?
The proof is a lot better, and it's great that you nailed down the requirement on the decay of beta, but the proof is still confusing in some places:

On pg 29, it says "That is, dividing the right equation in Eq. 5.8 with alpha, we write the ..." but the next equation doesn't obviously have anything to do with Eq. 5.8, and instead (I think) it comes from Eq 5.5. This could be clarified.

Later on page 29, you write "We now evoke the requirement that the averages xt and yt are stationary", but then you just repeat Eq. 5.11 and set it to zero. Clearly you needed the limit condition to set Eq. 5.11 to zero, but it's not clear what you're using stationarity for. I mean, if you needed stationarity for 5.11 presumably you would have referenced it at that step.

It could be helpful for readers if you could spell out the practical implications of the theorem's assumptions (other than the no-causality requirement) by discussing examples of setups where it would or wouldn't hold.
The following is the authors’ response to the previous reviews
We have made the following small adjustments and resubmit the manuscript to be published as a Version of Record with eLife.
Changes in main text of the manuscript:
We have moved the “Proposed additional tests” subsection to the Discussion section as suggested by the referee.

We have added a link to a Github repository and a link to a Zenodo data repository at the beginning of the Materials and Methods section in the “Data and materials availability” subsection. The Github repository contains simulation code and data, and single-cell data analysis code. The Zenodo link contains our experimental data (we await your confirmation before we publish it officially on Zenodo).
Changes in the supplemental information files

We have fixed the typo on page 29 of the SI in which Eq. (8) was referred to in a derivation. It should be Eq. (5) instead. We thank the referee for catching this mistake which has now been corrected.
We have fixed a typo on page 29 of SI, in which the word “evoke” is now “invoke”.
We have clarified the derivation on page 29 of the SI. The referee is correct that the limit condition was used to set the right-hand side of Eq. (5.11) to zero.
